## Overview

He primarily focuses on teaching theoretical computer science courses, including those pertaining to complexity and algorithms. His research interests are broadly rooted in **theoretical computer science** and extend into **computer science education**, reflecting a diverse academic portfolio.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Ladha specializes in a variety of interconnected research domains, with a strong emphasis on **cryptography**, **secure computation**, and **blockchain technology**. His work delves into *privacy-preserving technologies*, exploring how to conduct secure and auditable private computations on public blockchain platforms. Other key areas of his expertise include **game theory**, **distributed systems**, *smart contracts*, *theoretical computer science*, *software engineering*, *formal methods*, *complexity theory*, *computability*, *logic*, *algorithms*, *combinatorics*, and *quantum computing*.

*   Dr. Ladha has made significant contributions to the field of **secure private computation on blockchains**, particularly through his work enabling auditable, available, and resilient private computations using Multi-Party Computation (MPC) techniques. This research addresses the inherent public nature of blockchain code and data, thereby facilitating the use of robust public platforms for mission-critical applications requiring strict privacy.
*   He also played a key role in developing **GABLE (Garbled Autonomous Bots Leveraging Ethereum)**, a project focused on achieving secure private execution of applications, such as garbled state machines and circuits, on public computing infrastructures like the Ethereum blockchain. paper_abstract: The use of virtualization to abstract underlying hardware can aid in sharing such resources and in efficiently managing their use by high performance applications. Unfortunately, virtualization also prevents efficient access to accelerators, such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs), that have become critical components in the design and architecture of HPC systems. Supporting General Purpose computing on GPUs (GPGPU) with accelerators from different vendors presents significant challenges due to proprietary programming models, heterogeneity, and the need to share accelerator resources between different Virtual Machines (VMs). paper_abstract: OBJECTIVE To examine prospectively the emergence of behavioral signs of autism in the first years of life in infants at low and high risk for autism. METHOD A prospective longitudinal design was used to compare 25 infants later diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder (ASD) with 25 gender-matched low-risk children later determined to have typical development. paper_abstract: The widespread usage of WLANs and mobile devices has fostered the interest in localization systems for wireless environments. The majority of research in the context of wireless-based localization systems has focused on device-based active localization, in which devices are attached to tracked entities. Recently, device-free passive localization (DfP) has been proposed where the tracked entity is neither required to carry devices nor to participate actively in the localization process. Previous studies have focused on small areas and/or controlled environments. In this paper, we present the design, implementation, and analysis of Nuzzer, a large-scale DfP localization system, which tracks entities in real environments, rich in multipath. Five different and relevant keywords were used to extract tweets. researcher_keywords: Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, Information Extraction
paper_abstract: People tweet more than 100 Million times daily, yielding a noisy, informal, but sometimes informative corpus of 140-character messages that mirrors the zeitgeist in an unprecedented manner. The performance of standard NLP tools is severely degraded on tweets. This paper addresses this issue by re-building the NLP pipeline beginning with part-of-speech tagging, through chunking, to named-entity recognition. Our novel T-NER system doubles F1 score compared with the Stanford NER system. T-NER leverages the redundancy inherent in tweets to achieve this performance, using LabeledLDA to exploit Freebase dictionaries as a source of distant supervision. LabeledLDA outperforms cotraining, increasing F1 by 25% over ten common entity types.

paper_abstract: Traffic classification technology has increased in relevance this decade, as it is now used in the definition and implementation of mechanisms for service differentiation, network design and engineering, security, accounting, advertising, and research. Over the past 10 years the research community and the networking industry have investigated, proposed and developed several classification approaches. While traffic classification techniques are improving in accuracy and efficiency, the continued proliferation of different Internet application behaviors, in addition to growing incentives to disguise some applications to avoid filtering or blocking, are among the reasons that traffic classification remains one of many open problems in Internet research. paper_abstract: Background It is important for institutions of higher education to maintain academic integrity, both for students and the institutions themselves. Proctoring is one way of accomplishing this, and with the increasing popularity of online courses—along with the sudden shift to online education sparked by the COVID‐19 pandemic—digital proctoring has seen an increase in use. However, there are privacy and bias concerns related to digital proctoring, so it is important to critically examine its role in higher education—when it should and should not be used, and how it is perceived among those who interact with it. researcher_keywords: human-computer interaction, information visualization, visual analytics
paper_abstract: Space supports human cognitive abilities in a myriad of ways. The note attached to the side of the monitor, the papers spread out on the desk, diagrams scrawled on a whiteboard, and even the keys left out on the counter are all examples of using space to recall, reveal relationships, and think. Technological advances have made it possible to construct large display environments in which space has real meaning. This paper examines how increased space affects the way displays are regarded and used within the context of the cognitively demanding task of sensemaking. A pair of studies were conducted demonstrating how the spatial environment supports sensemaking by becoming part of the distributed cognitive process, providing both external memory and a semantic layer.

researcher_keywords: Ubiquitous Computing
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose BodyBeat, a novel mobile sensing system for capturing and recognizing a diverse range of non-speech body sounds in real-life scenarios. Non-speech body sounds, such as sounds of food intake, breath, laughter, and cough contain invaluable information about our dietary behavior, respiratory physiology, and affect. The BodyBeat mobile sensing system consists of a custom-built piezoelectric microphone and a distributed computational framework that utilizes an ARM microcontroller and an Android smartphone. The custom-built microphone is designed to capture subtle body vibrations directly from the body surface without being perturbed by external sounds. The microphone is attached to a 3D printed neckpiece with a suspension mechanism. The ARM embedded system and the Android smartphone process the acoustic signal from the microphone and identify non-speech body sounds. We have extensively evaluated the BodyBeat mobile sensing system. Our results show that BodyBeat outperforms other existing solutions in capturing and recognizing different types of important non-speech body sounds.

affiliation: Professor, School of Cybersecurity and Privacy, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Cryptography, Information Security
paper_abstract: We propose a robust proactive threshold signature scheme, a multisignature scheme and a blind signature scheme which work in any Gap Diffie-Hellman (GDH) group (where the Computational Diffie- Hellman problem is hard but the Decisional Diffie-Hellman problem is easy). Our constructions are based on the recently proposed GDH signature scheme of Boneh et al. . Due to the instrumental structure of GDH groups and of the base scheme, it turns out that most of our constructions are simpler, more efficient and have more useful properties than similar existing constructions. We support all the proposed schemes with proofs under the appropriate computational assumptions, using the corresponding notions of security.

researcher_keywords: Computer Architecture, Datacenter Systems, Memory Systems, Networking
paper_abstract: Emerging datacenter applications operate on vast datasets that are kept in DRAM to minimize latency. The large number of servers needed to accommodate this massive memory footprint requires frequent server-to-server communication in applications such as key-value stores and graph-based applications that rely on large irregular data structures. The fine-grained nature of the accesses is a poor match to commodity networking technologies, including RDMA, which incur delays of 10-1000x over local DRAM operations. We introduce Scale-Out NUMA (soNUMA) -- an architecture, programming model, and communication protocol for low-latency, distributed in-memory processing. soNUMA layers an RDMA-inspired programming model directly on top of a NUMA memory fabric via a stateless messaging protocol. To facilitate interactions between the application, OS, and the fabric, soNUMA relies on the remote …

## Research Areas

Dr. Daglis specializes in a broad array of research areas within computing systems. His research further extends to leveraging *SmartNICs for efficient Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs)* and investigating *error-resilient computing* techniques.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Daglis has significantly contributed to the development of **Scale-Out Non-Uniform Memory Access (NUMA)** architectures, which provide low-latency, distributed in-memory processing capabilities essential for modern datacenter applications handling vast datasets and requiring frequent, fine-grained server-to-server communication. This work improved the efficiency and performance of key-value stores and graph-based applications.
*   He pioneered research into **near-memory processing (NMP) architectures**, exemplified by projects like the Mondrian Data Engine. This work addresses the limitations of traditional CPU-centric designs by tightly coupling logic and memory, leading to substantial improvements in computing efficiency as Dennard scaling plateaus.
*   His research has extensively focused on optimizing **Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs)** in large-scale online services to meet stringent tail latency requirements. Through projects like RPCValet and NeBuLa, Dr. Daglis has designed novel architectures and leveraged hardware-terminated user-level protocols (e.g., SmartNICs) to drastically reduce inter-server communication overheads, ensuring faster and more responsive online services. More recently, he has introduced CXL-centric memory systems to further enhance server memory bandwidth and capacity, mitigating queuing delays for improved performance.

affiliation: Associate Professor, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Systems for ML, soft real-time ML, LLM inference
paper_abstract: The next generation of AI applications will continuously interact with the environment and learn from these interactions. These applications impose new and demanding systems requirements, both in terms of performance and flexibility. In this paper, we consider these requirements and present Ray—a distributed system to address them. Ray implements a unified interface that can express both task-parallel and actor-based computations, supported by a single dynamic execution engine. To meet the performance requirements, Ray employs a distributed scheduler and a distributed and fault-tolerant store to manage the system’s control state. In our experiments, we demonstrate scaling beyond 1.8 million tasks per second and better performance than existing specialized systems for several challenging reinforcement learning applications.

affiliation: Regents' Professor, Interactive Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: social computing, collaborative computing
paper_abstract: As the Internet has changed communication, commerce, and the distribution of information, so too it is changing psychological research. Psychologists can observe new or rare phenomena online and can do research on traditional psychological topics more efficiently, enabling them to expand the scale and scope of their research. Yet these opportunities entail risk both to research quality and to human subjects. Internet research is inherently no more risky than traditional observational, survey, or experimental methods. Yet the risks and safeguards against them will differ from those characterizing traditional research and will themselves change over time. This article describes some benefits and challenges of conducting psychological research via the Internet and offers recommendations to both researchers and institutional review boards for dealing with them.

His work also involves discovering unique cybersecurity vulnerabilities, analyzing their impact through large-scale studies, developing defenses with formal guarantees, and creating practical solutions to help users better understand their systems' security.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Chhotaray specializes in a diverse array of cybersecurity disciplines, including **Cryptography**, **Hardware Security**, and the multifaceted field of **Cyber-Physical Systems Security**. His expertise also spans into areas such as *Applied Cryptography, Network Security, Reverse Engineering, Intellectual Property Protection,* and the emerging fields of *Machine Learning Security* and *Embedded Systems Security*. Further research interests encompass *Digital Forensics*, supply-chain security for additive manufacturing (3D printing), and *Maritime Cybersecurity*, often incorporating user studies and machine learning techniques to address complex security challenges.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Chhotaray conducted a comprehensive analysis that exposed critical **cryptographic vulnerabilities** in a widely adopted industry standard for protecting electronic-design intellectual property, demonstrating how these flaws could be exploited to recover entire plaintext designs and even introduce targeted hardware Trojans. This pivotal work underscored the necessity for rigorous cryptographic design in industrial standards, leading to the identification of <u>seven Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE)</u>.
*   He established a **principled foundation for design-hiding techniques** aimed at protecting electronic circuits from reverse-engineering attacks. This research provided formal syntax and a framework for evaluating the security of schemes designed to obscure circuit functionality, addressing a long-standing gap in the field and contributing to the development of <u>provably secure hardware</u>.
*   He also developed an innovative solution, **PLCHound**, which facilitates the automated discovery and empirical security evaluation of <u>field-deployed Industrial Control System (ICS) equipment</u>, such as Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs), by leveraging active network data from internet-scale scanners. This tool significantly aids in attack-surface management and monitoring the adoption of vulnerability patches in critical infrastructure.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Chhotaray earned his **Ph.D. (2023)** and **M.S. (2017)** in *Computer Science* from the **University of Florida**. Prior to his graduate studies, he completed his **B.Tech. in Computer Science** from *NIT Rourkela, India*, in 2011. His professional journey began as an Engineer at Samsung Research & Development Institute, followed by a role as a Teaching Associate at KIIT University, before embarking on his graduate research and subsequent appointment as a Research Scientist at Georgia Tech in 2023.

He was recognized with the <u>Outstanding Research Scientist award</u> by the College of Computing at Georgia Tech in 2025, in addition to receiving Graduate Fellowship Awards in 2019 and 2022. Dr. Chhotaray is an active member of the Idaho National Laboratory's (INL) Education Working Group for the Department of Energy's (DoE) Cyber-Informed-Engineering (CIE) initiative and contributes to the IEEE P3528 CIE Guide for CIE Curricula, co-authoring the CIE Curriculum Guide V1. He also co-manages the Cyber-Physical System Security lab and instructs graduate students in cybersecurity and AI research within Georgia Tech's OMSCS program.

affiliation: Georgia Institute of Technology, University of Toronto
researcher_keywords: Robotic Manipulation, Robot Learning, Reinforcement Learning, Machine Learning, Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Task planning can require defining myriad domain knowledge about the world in which a robot needs to act. To ameliorate that effort, large language models (LLMs) can be used to score potential next actions during task planning, and even generate action sequences directly, given an instruction in natural language with no additional domain information. However, such methods either require enumerating all possible next steps for scoring, or generate free-form text that may contain actions not possible on a given robot in its current context. We present a programmatic LLM prompt structure that enables plan generation functional across situated environments, robot capabilities, and tasks. Our key insight is to prompt the LLM with program-like specifications of the available actions and objects in an environment, as well as with example programs that can be executed. We make concrete recommendations about prompt structure and generation constraints through ablation experiments, demonstrate state of the art success rates in VirtualHome household tasks, and deploy our method on a physical robot arm for tabletop tasks. Website at progprompt.github.io

Professor Garg leads the **People, AI, and Robotics (PAIR) research group**, where his primary research vision is to develop the <u>Algorithmic Foundations for Generalizable Autonomy</u>, enabling robots to acquire skills at both cognitive and dexterous levels and to seamlessly interact with humans in novel environments. His work emphasizes understanding structured inductive biases and causality in the pursuit of general-purpose embodied intelligence that learns from imprecise information and achieves the flexibility and efficiency of human reasoning.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Garg's specialization encompasses a broad spectrum of research fields, including **Robotics**, **Machine Learning**, and **Reinforcement Learning**. His work deeply integrates *Computer Vision, Robotic Manipulation, Robot Learning,* and *Imitation Learning* to address complex challenges in autonomous systems. He also delves into areas such as *Motion Planning, Control Theory, Artificial Intelligence,* and the development of multimodal representations for robust human-robot interaction. A significant aspect of his research focuses on <u>generalizable autonomy</u>, aiming to build robots that can adapt to diverse tasks and environments by learning from data-driven causal discovery and transferring knowledge to real-world applications.

---

## Notable Works

*   Professor Garg has made significant contributions to *robot task planning* by developing methods that leverage **large language models** to generate and evaluate robot action sequences directly from natural language instructions. This innovation substantially reduces the need for extensive manual domain knowledge, making it easier for robots to understand and execute complex tasks in various settings.
*   He is recognized for inventing **RoboTurk**, a pioneering <u>crowdsourcing platform for robotic skill learning through imitation</u>. This platform has been instrumental in collecting large, high-quality datasets of human demonstrations, addressing the sample complexity issues prevalent in reinforcement learning and thereby accelerating the development of robotic manipulation skills.
*   Another key contribution includes the development of **differentiable simulation engines**, such as DiSECt, which enable <u>autonomous robotic cutting of soft materials</u>. This work allows for gradient-based optimization in complex, contact-rich tasks, greatly facilitating the verification of robot controllers, learning new policies, and generating diverse datasets for surgical and manufacturing applications.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Garg earned his **Ph.D. in Operations Research**, with a minor in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, from *UC Berkeley* in 2016, where he also received an **M.S. in Computer Science**. Prior to this, he obtained an **M.S. in Industrial Engineering** from the *Georgia Institute of Technology* in 2011 and a **B.E. in Manufacturing Processes & Automation Engineering** from Netaji Subhas Institute of Technology, University of Delhi, India, in 2010. He completed his postdoctoral research at the *Stanford AI Lab*, working with **Fei-Fei Li** and **Silvio Savarese** from 2016 to 2018. His distinguished career trajectory includes being named a *Canada CIFAR AI Chair* in 2020 and receiving the *Stanford-Coulter Translational Research Award* in 2018. He was also recognized as an *AAAI New Faculty Highlights Invited Speaker* in 2021 and is slated as a *World Summit AI Keynote Speaker* for 2025. His work has garnered several accolades, including the *Best Conference Paper Award at IEEE ICRA 2024* and the *Best Student Paper Award at RSS'21* for his work on DiSECt.

affiliation: Chair and Professor, School of Interactive Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Software Engineering, Requirements Engineering, Privacy, Security, & Regulatory Compliance
paper_abstract: Goals are a logical mechanism for identifying, organizing and justifying software requirements. Strategies are needed for the initial identification and construction of goals. We discuss goals from the perspective of two themes: goal analysis and goal evolution. We begin with an overview of the goal-based method we have developed and summarize our experiences in applying our method to a relatively large example. We illustrate some of the issues that practitioners face when using a goal-based approach to specify the requirements for a system and close the paper with a discussion of needed future research on goal-based requirements analysis and evolution.

## Overview

She is also the founder and director of **ThePrivacyPlace.org**, a prominent research center dedicated to the intricate relationship between information systems and privacy protection. Her primary research centers on ensuring the <u>complete and correct behavior of software systems</u> that must comply with federal privacy and security regulations, focusing on methods and tools to achieve this alignment. Her work directly addresses the challenges of specifying software that handles sensitive information while mitigating risks of misuse and non-compliance.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Antón specializes in a diverse range of research areas at the intersection of computing, law, and policy. Her expertise spans **Software Engineering**, with a strong emphasis on *Requirements Engineering*, including goal-based and inquiry-based analysis and scenario management. She is a leading figure in **Privacy Engineering** and **Security Engineering**, focusing on the specification and analysis of privacy policies, user perceptions of privacy, and secure system design.

A significant portion of her work is dedicated to **Regulatory Compliance** and **Legal Informatics**, involving the extraction of rights and obligations from complex legal texts to align software system requirements with legal mandates. She also conducts research in *Human-Computer Interaction* related to user privacy values, *Information Policy*, and leverages *Natural Language Processing* for automating the analysis of policy documents.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Antón pioneered **Goal-Based Requirements Analysis (GBRAM)**, a seminal contribution to software engineering that provides a logical and systematic mechanism for identifying, organizing, and justifying software requirements. This work was recognized as the "Most Influential Paper of ICRE 1996" at RE'06, profoundly shaping how practitioners specify and refine complex systems.
*   She developed innovative methods and tools for **extracting and analyzing rights and obligations from complex legal and regulatory texts**, such as those governing privacy and security. *   As the founder and director of **ThePrivacyPlace.org**, she leads a multidisciplinary research initiative focused on developing technologies to assist practitioners and policymakers in eliciting and expressing robust privacy policies. This effort ensures that organizational privacy commitments are accurately reflected in and enforced by the underlying software systems.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Antón is a distinguished alumna of the *Georgia Institute of Technology*, where she earned her **Ph.D. in Computer Science** in 1997, along with an M.S. in 1992 and a B.S. in 1990. Prior to her tenure at Georgia Tech, she served as a Professor of Computer Science at *North Carolina State University* from 1998 to 2012.

Her contributions to the field have been widely recognized, including being named an **ACM Distinguished Scientist** in 2009 and receiving an **NSF CAREER Award** in 2000. In 2016, President Barack Obama appointed her to the 12-person bipartisan **Commission on Enhancing National Cybersecurity**, highlighting her expertise and influence in critical national policy. She also co-founded the annual *Requirements Engineering and the Law (RELAW) Workshop* and has held advisory roles on various influential boards, including the NIST Information Security & Privacy Advisory Board.

affiliation: Assistant Professor, Computational Science and Engineering, Georgia Tech
researcher_keywords: machine learning, computational and statistical neuroscience
paper_abstract: Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) hold great promise as a flexible and principled solution to deal with uncertainty when learning from finite data. Among approaches to realize probabilistic inference in deep neural networks, variational Bayes (VB) is theoretically grounded, generally applicable, and computationally efficient. With wide recognition of potential advantages, why is it that variational Bayes has seen very limited practical use for BNNs in real applications? We argue that variational inference in neural networks is fragile: successful implementations require careful initialization and tuning of prior variances, as well as controlling the variance of Monte Carlo gradient estimates. We provide two innovations that aim to turn VB into a robust inference tool for Bayesian neural networks: first, we introduce a novel deterministic method to approximate moments in neural networks, eliminating gradient variance; second, we introduce a hierarchical prior for parameters and a novel Empirical Bayes procedure for automatically selecting prior variances. Combining these two innovations, the resulting method is highly efficient and robust. On the application of heteroscedastic regression we demonstrate good predictive performance over alternative approaches.

affiliation: Professor of Computer Science and Human-Centered Computing, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Computational Design, AI, Cognitive Science, Educational Technology, Online Education
paper_abstract: Biologically inspired engineering design uses analogies to biological systems to develop solutions for engineering problems. We conducted a study of biologically inspired design in the context of an interdisciplinary introductory course on biologically inspired engineering design in Fall of 2006. The goals of this study were to understand the process of biologically inspired engineering design and to provide insight into biologically inspired design as a type of design activity. This paper provides a descriptive account of biologically inspired design processes and products, and summarizes our main observations: 1) designers use two distinct starting points for biologically inspired design; 2) regular patterns of practice emerge in biologically inspired design; and 3) certain errors occur regularly in the design process.

paper_abstract: In this paper, we present Esense: a new paradigm of communication between devices that have fundamentally different physical layers. The same communication framework also works between devices that have the same physical layer, which are out of communication range but within carrier-sense range. Esense is based on sensing and interpreting energy profiles. While our ideas are generic enough to be applicable in a variety of contexts, we illustrate the usefulness of our ideas by presenting novel solutions to existing problems in three distinct research domains. As part of these solutions, we demonstrate the ability to communicate between devices that follow two different standards: IEEE 802.11 and 802.15.4. We build an ``alphabet set'': a set of signature packet sizes which can be used for Esense. For this, we take a measurement based approach by considering WiFi traces from actual deployments. researcher_keywords: Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Kernel classifiers and regressors designed for structured data, such as sequences, trees and graphs, have significantly advanced a number of interdisciplinary areas such as computational biology and drug design. Typically, kernels are designed beforehand for a data type which either exploit statistics of the structures or make use of probabilistic generative models, and then a discriminative classifier is learned based on the kernels via convex optimization. However, such an elegant two-stage approach also limited kernel methods from scaling up to millions of data points, and exploiting discriminative information to learn feature representations. We propose, structure2vec, an effective and scalable approach for structured data representation based on the idea of embedding latent variable models into feature spaces, and learning such feature spaces using discriminative information. Interestingly, structure2vec extracts features by performing a sequence of function mappings in a way similar to graphical model inference procedures, such as mean field and belief propagation. In applications involving millions of data points, we showed that structure2vec runs 2 times faster, produces models which are 10,000 times smaller, while at the same time achieving the state-of-the-art predictive performance.

paper_abstract: In this article, we present a novel two-scale framework to optimize the structure and the material distribution of an object given its functional specifications. Our approach utilizes multi-material microstructures as low-level building blocks of the object. We start by precomputing the material property gamut—the set of bulk material properties that can be achieved with all material microstructures of a given size. We represent the boundary of this material property gamut using a level set field. Next, we propose an efficient and general topology optimization algorithm that simultaneously computes an optimal object topology and spatially varying material properties constrained by the precomputed gamut. Finally, we map the optimal spatially varying material properties onto the microstructures with the corresponding properties to generate a high-resolution printable structure. We demonstrate the efficacy of our framework by …

researcher_keywords: Cyber Forensics, Systems Security, Malware Analysis
paper_abstract: Advanced cyber attacks consist of multiple stages aimed at being stealthy and elusive. Such attack patterns leave their footprints spatio-temporally dispersed across many different logs in victim machines. However, existing log-mining intrusion analysis systems typically target only a single type of log to discover evidence of an attack and therefore fail to exploit fundamental inter-log connections. The output of such single-log analysis can hardly reveal the complete attack story for complex, multi-stage attacks. Additionally, some existing approaches require heavyweight system instrumentation, which makes them impractical to deploy in real production environments. To address these problems, we present HERCULE, an automated multi-stage log-based intrusion analysis system. Inspired by graph analytics research in social network analysis, we model multi-stage intrusion analysis as a community discovery problem …

researcher_keywords: Machine Learning, Multiagent Systems, Computer Vision, Robotics
paper_abstract: A classic example of multiagent coordination in a shared environment involves the use of pheromone deposits as a communication mechanism. Due to physical limitations in deploying actual pheromones, we propose a sparse representation of the pheromones using movable beacons. There is no communication between the beacons to propagate pheromones; instead, robots make movement and update decisions based entirely on local pheromone values. Robots deploy the beacons throughout the environment, and subsequently move them and update them using a variation of value iteration. Simulation results show that our approach is effective at finding good trails, locally improving them, and adapting to dynamic changes in the environments.

Buffer overflow attacks gained notoriety in 1988 as part of the Morris Worm incident on the Internet. Hundreds of attacks have been discovered, and while most of the obvious vulnerabilities have now been patched, more sophisticated buffer overflow attacks continue to emerge.We describe StackGuard: a simple compiler technique that virtually eliminates buffer overflow vulnerabilities with only modest performance penalties. researcher_keywords: Design
paper_abstract: An exploration of the political qualities of technology design, as seen in projects that span art, computer science, and consumer products. In Adversarial Design, Carl DiSalvo examines the ways that technology design can provoke and engage the political. He describes a practice, which he terms “adversarial design,” that uses the means and forms of design to challenge beliefs, values, and what is taken to be fact. It is not simply applying design to politics—attempting to improve governance for example, by redesigning ballots and polling places; it is implicitly contestational and strives to question conventional approaches to political issues. DiSalvo explores the political qualities and potentials of design by examining a series of projects that span design and art, engineering and computer science, agitprop and consumer products. He views these projects—which include computational visualizations of networks of power and influence, therapy robots that shape sociability, and everyday objects embedded with microchips that enable users to circumvent surveillance—through the lens of agonism, a political theory that emphasizes contention as foundational to democracy. DiSalvo's illuminating analysis aims to provide design criticism with a new approach for thinking about the relationship between forms of political expression, computation as a medium, and the processes and products of design.

paper_abstract: In response to calls for research to improve human-machine teaming (HMT), we present a “perspective” paper that explores techniques from computer science that can enhance machine agents for human-machine teams. As part of this paper, we (1) summarize the state of the science on critical team competencies identified for effective HMT, (2) discuss technological gaps preventing machines from fully realizing these competencies, and (3) identify ways that emerging artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities may address these gaps and enhance performance in HMT. We extend beyond extant literature by incorporating recent technologies and techniques and describing their potential for contributing to the advancement of HMT.

He also explores how data derived from human learning and decision-making can be harnessed to refine cognitive models and enhance computational learning systems.

## Research Areas

Her current book project, *The Volatile World: Agile Governance, AI, and the Politics of Fire Prediction in Indonesia*, investigates how environmental data and artificial intelligence are employed to predict and manage highly volatile fires in Indonesia's tropical peatland.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Lin specializes in a diverse range of research areas, including **Science and Technology Studies (STS)**, **Critical Data Studies**, and **Feminist Technoscience**. Her work extensively explores **Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)**, *Postcolonial Studies*, **Digital Humanities**, and **Environmental Studies**, particularly focusing on the intersection of these fields with **sociotechnical systems** and **AI Ethics**. She is also engaged in *Design Studies*, examining how technology is shaped by and, in turn, shapes societal values and power dynamics. Her scholarship frequently addresses themes of **digital precarity**, *techno-optimism*, and the ethical implications of data and AI in various global contexts.

paper_abstract: A viewer can extract many potential patterns from any set of visualized data values. But that means that two people can see different patterns in the same visualization, potentially leading to miscommunication. Here, we show that when people are primed to see one pattern in the data as visually salient, they believe that naïve viewers will experience the same visual salience. Participants were told one of multiple backstories about political events that affected public polling data, before viewing a graph that depicted those data. One pattern in the data was particularly visually salient to them given the backstory that they heard. They then predicted what naïve viewers would most visually salient on the visualization. They were strongly influenced by their own knowledge, despite explicit instructions to ignore it, predicting that others would find the same patterns to be most visually salient. ## Overview

**Cindy Xiong Bearfield** is currently an *Assistant Professor* in the **School of Interactive Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*, having joined in January 2024. Her primary research centers on the intersection of <u>visual perception, cognition, and data visualization</u>. She investigates how the design of visualizations influences human understanding, decision-making, and critical thinking. A key objective of her work is to develop models to measure and enhance <u>trust in human-data interaction</u> through effective visual data communication.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Xiong Bearfield specializes in a broad range of research areas, including **Information Visualization**, **Visual Perception**, **Decision Making**, **Cognitive Psychology**, and **Human-Computer Interaction**. Her expertise also extends to *Decision Science, Data Communication, Experimental Psychology, Computer Vision, Machine Learning Interpretability,* and *Educational Psychology*. She actively examines cognitive and perceptual biases in visual data interpretation, such as the *curse of knowledge* and the *illusion of causality*, and explores how these biases can be mitigated or amplified by visualization design choices. Her work also delves into the ethical implications of visualization, including its impact on *social outcomes* and *political polarization*.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Xiong Bearfield has made significant contributions by revealing how **pre-existing beliefs and visualization designs** can introduce cognitive biases, such as the "curse of knowledge" and the "illusion of causality," in how viewers interpret data. Her research highlights that people may perceive different patterns from the same visualization, influencing their causal reasoning and potentially leading to miscommunication. This work provides crucial insights for designing visualizations that promote more objective and accurate data interpretation by anticipating and mitigating these inherent biases.
*   She has developed **frameworks for evaluating data visualizations** across different levels of human understanding, drawing inspiration from educational literature like Bloom's taxonomy. This foundational work helps practitioners diagnose how effectively visualizations support a viewer's ability to extract facts, understand context, and draw conclusions. Additionally, her empirical evaluations of design guidelines, such as "declutter and focus," offer practical strategies for creating clearer and more efficient visual data communication.
*   A core aspect of her research explores the **multidimensional nature of trust in data visualizations** and its critical role in decision-making. Her studies examine how elements like metadata, transparency, and specific design choices impact a viewer's trust. This includes investigating how visual designs affect perceived bias in machine learning models, ultimately aiming to foster "calibrated trust" where users critically evaluate information and contribute to the development of more responsible and fair AI systems.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Xiong Bearfield earned her **Ph.D. in Psychology** from *Northwestern University*. Before joining *Georgia Tech*, she served as an **Assistant Professor** at the *College of Information and Computer Science* at the University of Massachusetts Amherst from 2021 to 2024. While at UMass, she was awarded a prestigious **National Science Foundation (NSF) CAREER Award**. Her career trajectory demonstrates a strong interdisciplinary approach, combining cognitive science with computer science to address fundamental questions in data visualization and human-computer interaction. She is also actively involved with the **IEEE Computer Society Technical Community on Visualization and Graphics**, serving on its Executive Committee.

researcher_keywords: Geographic Information Science, Urban Planning, Social Networks, Info Vis
paper_abstract: Do regional boundaries defined by governments respect the more natural ways that people interact across space? This paper proposes a novel, fine-grained approach to regional delineation, based on analyzing networks of billions of individual human transactions. Given a geographical area and some measure of the strength of links between its inhabitants, we show how to partition the area into smaller, non-overlapping regions while minimizing the disruption to each person's links. We tested our method on the largest non-Internet human network, inferred from a large telecommunications database in Great Britain. Our partitioning algorithm yields geographically cohesive regions that correspond remarkably well with administrative regions, while unveiling unexpected spatial structures that had previously only been hypothesized in the literature. We also quantify the effects of partitioning, showing for instance that the effects of a possible secession of Wales from Great Britain would be twice as disruptive for the human network than that of Scotland.

She also serves as the **Co-Director** of the **MS-GIST Program**. Dr. Andris directs the **Friendly Cities Lab**, where her primary research focuses on utilizing <u>geographic information science, social networks, and spatial networks</u> to understand and model human interactions and their impact on urban environments. Her work specifically explores how these interactions shape cities, influence urban planning, and can be visualized through advanced geovisualization techniques.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Andris specializes in a diverse range of interconnected research areas, prominently including **Geographic Information Science (GIScience)**, **Urban Planning**, and **Social Network Analysis**. Her expertise extends to *Information Visualization* and *Geovisualization*, where she develops tools and methods to represent complex spatial and social data. Key areas of her specialization also encompass <u>Spatial Data Analysis, Human Geography, Urban Mobility, Computational Social Science, Geospatial Privacy, and Machine Learning in Geography</u>. A significant portion of her research involves developing mathematical models of social networks, social flows, and interpersonal relationships to better understand how these dynamics influence urban spaces and aid in creating more connected and responsive cities.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Andris has made significant contributions to regional analysis by developing a novel approach to <u>delineate geographical regions based on actual human interaction networks</u>. This method leverages billions of individual human transactions to partition areas in a way that minimizes disruption to people's existing social and economic links, offering a more natural and socially informed understanding of regional boundaries.
*   Her research has also provided crucial insights into urban mobility by systematically analyzing large-scale digital traces of individuals, such as taxi drivers. This work reveals underlying <u>behavioral patterns and "mobility intelligence,"</u> demonstrating how digital footprints can be used to understand operational strategies and movement dynamics within complex urban contexts.
*   During the COVID-19 pandemic, Dr. Andris led the development of a <u>real-time, interactive online dashboard</u> that estimated the risk of SARS-CoV-2 presence in gatherings at the U.S. county level. This tool provided vital geolocalized risk information to the public, aiding in informed decision-making regarding events and gatherings and helping to counteract risk misestimation.
*   Furthermore, her work profoundly impacts urban planning by enriching **Points of Interest (POI) data** with information about social relationships, visitor diversity, and the prevalence of chain establishments versus independent businesses. This research helps urban planners identify amenities that best support <u>personal relationships and foster unique, authentic local landscapes</u>, ultimately contributing to the design of more "friendly cities."

## Academic Background

Dr. Andris earned her **Ph.D. in Urban Information Systems** from the *Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)* in 2011, where she was an **NDSEG fellow** and a member of the **Senseable City Lab**. Following her doctoral studies, she held postdoctoral positions at the *Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology* and the *Santa Fe Institute*.

Prior to joining *Georgia Tech*, she served as a faculty member in the **Department of Geography** at *Penn State University*. Her significant achievements include receiving an **NSF CAREER award in 2021**. Dr. Andris actively contributes to the broader geospatial community, serving on the **National Geospatial Advisory Committee**. Her academic journey highlights a consistent focus on the intersection of geography, computing, and urban studies, fostering innovative approaches to understanding and shaping cities.

researcher_keywords: Neuro-inspired Machine Learning, Network Science, Computational Science
paper_abstract: In a packet network, the terms bandwidth and throughput often characterize the amount of data that the network can transfer per unit of time. Bandwidth estimation is of interest to users wishing to optimize end-to-end transport performance, overlay network routing, and peer-to-peer file distribution. Techniques for accurate bandwidth estimation are also important for traffic engineering and capacity planning support. Existing bandwidth estimation tools measure one or more of three related metrics: capacity, available bandwidth, and bulk transfer capacity. Currently available bandwidth estimation tools employ a variety of strategies to measure these metrics. In this survey we review the recent bandwidth estimation literature focusing on underlying techniques and methodologies as well as open source bandwidth measurement tools.

researcher_keywords: Algorithms, Theoretical Computer Science
paper_abstract: We present the first optimal randomized online algorithms for the TCP acknowledgment problem [5] and the Bahncard problem [7]. These problems are well-known to be generalizations of the classical online ski rental problem, however, they appeared to be harder. In this paper, we demonstrate that a number of online algorithms which have optimal competitive ratios of e/(e-1), including these, are fundamentally no more complex than ski rental. Our results also suggest a clear paradigm for solving ski rental-like problems.

researcher_keywords: Educational Technology, Learning at Scale, AI in Education, Online Education, Computer Science Education
paper_abstract: Despite the ubiquitous use of instructional videos in both formal and informal learning settings, questions remain largely unanswered on how to design and develop video lessons that are often used as the primary method for delivering instruction in online courses. In this study, we experimented with a model of seven principles drawn from instructional design theories for designing and developing video lessons for an online graduate course. Feedback was collected from students through surveys on their perceptions of the effectiveness of the video lessons and the overall course quality for eight semesters. This paper shares the instructors' experience on the design and development of the video lessons as well as the survey findings. Implications of the findings for instructional design and future research are also discussed.

researcher_keywords: scientific computing, high-performance computing, numerical methods
paper_abstract: Although molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of biomolecular systems often run for days to months, many events of great scientific interest and pharmaceutical relevance occur on long time scales that remain beyond reach. paper_abstract: We present Lift & Learn, a physics-informed method for learning low-dimensional models for large-scale dynamical systems. The method exploits knowledge of a system’s governing equations to identify a coordinate transformation in which the system dynamics have quadratic structure. This transformation is called a lifting map because it often adds auxiliary variables to the system state. The lifting map is applied to data obtained by evaluating a model for the original nonlinear system. This lifted data is projected onto its leading principal components, and low-dimensional linear and quadratic matrix operators are fit to the lifted reduced data using a least-squares operator inference procedure. Analysis of our method shows that the Lift & Learn models are able to capture the system physics in the lifted coordinates at least as accurately as traditional intrusive model reduction approaches. paper_abstract: Graphs are commonly used to model the structure of internetworks, for the study of problems ranging from routing to resource reservation. A variety of graph models are found in the literature, including regular topologies such as rings or stars, "well-known" topologies such as the original ARPAnet, and randomly generated topologies. Less common is any discussion of how closely these models correlate with real network topologies. We compare the properties of graphs generated using various methods with those of real internets. We also propose efficient methods for generating topologies with particular properties, including a transit-stub model that correlates well with the internet structure. paper_abstract: Seismic data recovery from data with missing traces on otherwise regular acquisition grids forms a crucial step in the seismic processing flow. For instance, unsuccessful recovery leads to imaging artefacts and to erroneous predictions for the multiples, adversely affecting the performance of multiple elimination. A non-parametric transform-based recovery method is presented that exploits the compression of seismic data volumes by recently developed curvelet frames. The elements of this transform are multidimensional and directional and locally resemble wave fronts present in the data, which leads to a compressible representation for seismic data. ## Notable Works

*   Dr. Herrmann pioneered the application of **compressive sensing** techniques, including randomized survey design and wavefield reconstruction via sparse inversion, to transform seismic data acquisition. This work has tangible benefits for the oil and gas industry by *reducing exploration investment* and <u>minimizing environmental harm</u>.
*   He played a key role in the development of **Devito**, an *embedded domain-specific language* that facilitates the implementation of high-performance finite-difference partial differential equation solvers. This tool is critical for tackling the immense computational demands of methods like **full-waveform inversion** and *reverse-time migration* in exploration seismology.
*   His contributions include developing widely adopted **curvelet-based denoising and matched filtering methods** for seismic data. Dr. Herrmann also significantly advanced **full-waveform inversion** and reverse-time migration by introducing concepts from <u>stochastic and constrained optimization</u>, leading to high-fidelity imaging results with reduced computational expenditures. He is also actively involved in developing **Digital Twin frameworks** for geological carbon storage, leveraging machine learning and Bayesian inference for monitoring and forecasting.

In 2017, he joined the **Georgia Institute of Technology**. Dr. Herrmann was recognized as the **2019 SEG Distinguished Lecturer** and is a co-founder and director of the **Center for Machine Learning for Seismic (ML4Seismic)** at Georgia Tech, fostering industrial research partnerships in AI-assisted seismic imaging.

researcher_keywords: Computer Architecture, Computer Systems, Databases, AI
paper_abstract: Despite existing work in machine learning inference serving, ease-of-use and cost efficiency remain challenges at large scales. Developers must manually search through thousands of model-variants—versions of already-trained models that differ in hardware, resource footprints, latencies, costs, and accuracies—to meet the diverse application requirements. Since requirements, query load, and applications themselves evolve over time, these decisions need to be made dynamically for each inference query to avoid excessive costs through naive autoscaling. To avoid navigating through the large and complex trade-off space of model-variants, developers often fix a variant across queries, and replicate it when load increases. However, given the diversity across variants and hardware platforms in the cloud, a lack of understanding of the trade-off space can incur significant costs to developers.

researcher_keywords: Robotics, Control and Optimization, Machine Learning, Safe Autonomy, Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: We extend the learning from demonstration paradigm by providing a method for learning unknown constraints shared across tasks, using demonstrations of the tasks, their cost functions, and knowledge of the system dynamics and control constraints. Given safe demonstrations, our method uses hit-and-run sampling to obtain lower cost, and thus unsafe, trajectories. Both safe and unsafe trajectories are used to obtain a consistent representation of the unsafe set via solving an integer program. Our method generalizes across system dynamics and learns a guaranteed subset of the constraint. We also provide theoretical analysis on what subset of the constraint can be learnable from safe demonstrations. We demonstrate our method on linear and nonlinear system dynamics, show that it can be modified to work with suboptimal demonstrations, and that it can also be used to learn constraints in a feature space.

paper_abstract: In this paper we introduce a new algorithm for image and video texture synthesis. In our approach, patch regions from a sample image or video are transformed and copied to the output and then stitched together along optimal seams to generate a new (and typically larger) output. In contrast to other techniques, the size of the patch is not chosen a-priori, but instead a graph cut technique is used to determine the optimal patch region for any given offset between the input and output texture. Unlike dynamic programming, our graph cut technique for seam optimization is applicable in any dimension. We specifically explore it in 2D and 3D to perform video texture synthesis in addition to regular image synthesis. We present approximative offset search techniques that work well in conjunction with the presented patch size optimization. We show results for synthesizing regular, random, and natural images and videos. We …

**Greg Turk** is a distinguished *Professor* in the **School of Interactive Computing** within the *College of Computing* at the **Georgia Institute of Technology**. His primary research endeavors span the critical intersections of <u>computer graphics</u>, **biological simulation**, and **scientific visualization**. Professor Turk's work also encompasses significant contributions to **robotics** and the evolving field of **machine learning**.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Turk's expertise covers a broad spectrum of research areas within computer science, including **Computer Graphics**, **Robotics**, and **Scientific Visualization**. His specialization extends to *Geometric Modeling*, with a focus on **Implicit Surfaces** and **Surface Reconstruction** techniques, as evidenced by his seminal work on zippered polygon meshes. Furthermore, he has made substantial contributions to **Texture Synthesis**, particularly using *reaction-diffusion* processes and *graph cuts*, and to **Physics-Based Animation**, including the simulation of fluids and deformable materials. More recently, his interests have expanded into **Machine Learning** and **Computational Geometry**, specifically addressing topics like *robot control policies* and *human dressing animation*.

## Notable Works

*   One of Dr. Turk's most significant contributions is the development of a method for **zippering polygon meshes from range images**, which revolutionized the reconstruction of surfaces from point cloud data. *   He is also highly recognized for his pioneering research in **texture synthesis**, particularly his early work demonstrating how *reaction-diffusion systems* could generate realistic patterns on arbitrary surfaces. Later contributions, such as "Graphcut textures," advanced image and video synthesis by optimizing patch stitching for seamless texture generation.
*   Dr. Turk's efforts in **simplification and level-of-detail approximations** for polygonal models have been impactful, with methods like "Re-tiling polygonal surfaces" and "Simplification envelopes" providing efficient ways to manage geometric complexity while maintaining visual fidelity. He subsequently conducted postdoctoral research at *Stanford University* from 1992 to 1994, collaborating with **Marc Levoy**, and then served as a research professor back at UNC-Chapel Hill until 1996. Dr. Turk joined the faculty at **Georgia Tech** in 1996, where he has since risen to the rank of Professor. His significant contributions to the field have been recognized with an **NSF CAREER Award** in 1997 and the prestigious **ACM Computer Graphics Achievement Award** in 2012 for his work on physically-inspired mathematical applications in graphics. He also served as the **Technical Papers Chair for SIGGRAPH 2008**.

## Overview

**Haesun Park** is currently a *Regents' Professor* and <u>Chair</u> in the **School of Computational Science and Engineering (CSE)** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. She also held the position of the School's first external hire and later its first associate chair upon her arrival in 2005, becoming the <u>first woman to ascend to the chair position in 2020</u>. Her primary research focuses on <u>numerical computing, large-scale data analysis, and visual analytics</u>, with applications spanning bioinformatics, text mining, and homeland security. She is dedicated to developing foundational mathematical and computational theories, algorithms, and software to address the challenges of massive data analysis.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Park specializes in a diverse range of research areas, including **Numerical Algorithms**, **Data Analysis**, **Visual Analytics**, and **Parallel Computing**. Her work extensively covers *Machine Learning, Data Mining, Pattern Recognition, Computer Vision, Bioinformatics, Applied Mathematics, Numerical Analysis, Scientific Computing, Signal Processing,* and *Information Retrieval*. A significant portion of her research centers on <u>Nonnegative Matrix Factorization (NMF)</u> and its variations, which she applies to problems such as <u>clustering, dimension reduction, and topic modeling</u>, including the development of high-performance software for NMF. She has also made substantial contributions to **Generalized Discriminant Analysis** for feature extraction and classification, especially in undersampled problems.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Park has significantly advanced the field of <u>Nonnegative Matrix Factorization (NMF)</u> by providing systematic analyses of its various forms, including orthogonal and sparse NMF, and extending its application for rigorous clustering interpretations and graph clustering. This work has enabled more meaningful and interpretable low-rank approximations of data in numerous applications, from image processing to bioinformatics.
*   She developed innovative <u>dimension reduction techniques</u>, such as those based on generalized singular value decomposition (GSVD) and discriminant analysis, to effectively handle high-dimensional and undersampled data. These methods have been crucial for improving efficiency and preserving data structure in areas like text classification and face recognition.
*   Her contributions to **Foundations of Data and Visual Analytics (FODAVA)**, where she served as the lead director, involved creating a multidisciplinary framework that integrates advanced data analysis algorithms with interactive visual interfaces. This initiative aimed to enhance analytical reasoning and knowledge extraction from complex datasets for critical applications, including homeland security.

## Academic Background

Prior to her graduate studies, she received a **B.S. in Mathematics** from *Seoul National University* in 1981, graduating with the Presidential Medal for being the top graduate.

Before joining *Georgia Tech* in 2005, she was a <u>professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities</u> from 1987 to 2005, and also served as a <u>program director in the Computing and Communication Foundations Division at the National Science Foundation</u> from 2003 to 2005. Her profound impact on the field has been recognized through her election as a **SIAM Fellow in 2013**, an **IEEE Fellow in 2016**, and an **ACM Fellow in 2020** for her outstanding contributions to numerical computing, data analysis, and visual analytics. She has held editorial board positions for leading computational science and engineering journals and has been a plenary keynote speaker at major international conferences.

paper_abstract: In the context of robotics and automation, learning from demonstration (LfD) is the paradigm in which robots acquire new skills by learning to imitate an expert. The choice of LfD over other robot learning methods is compelling when ideal behavior can be neither easily scripted (as is done in traditional robot programming) nor easily defined as an optimization problem, but can be demonstrated. While there have been multiple surveys of this field in the past, there is a need for a new one given the considerable growth in the number of publications in recent years. This review aims to provide an overview of the collection of machine-learning methods used to enable a robot to learn from and imitate a teacher. We focus on recent advancements in the field and present an updated taxonomy and characterization of existing methods. We also discuss mature and emerging application areas for LfD and highlight the …

He directs the **Structured Techniques for Algorithmic Robotics (STAR) Lab**. researcher_keywords: Parallel Algorithms, Caching, Performance Engineering
paper_abstract: Perhaps the most popular sparse graph storage format is Compressed Sparse Row (CSR). CSR excels at storing graphs compactly with minimal overhead, allowing for fast traversals, lookups, and basic graph computations such as PageRank. Since elements in CSR format are packed together, additions and deletions often require time linear in the size of the graph. We introduce a new dynamic sparse graph representation called Packed Compressed Sparse Row (PCSR), based on an array-based dynamic data structure called the Packed Memory Array. PCSR is similar to CSR, but leaves spaces between elements, allowing for asymptotically faster insertions and deletions in exchange for a constant factor slowdown in traversals and a constant factor increase in space overhead. Our contributions are twofold. We describe PCSR and review the theoretical guarantees for update, insert, and search for PCSR. We …

researcher_keywords: 𝐇𝐢𝐠𝐡 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐀𝐈, Computer Vision, Multimodal, Creative AI, AI Systems
paper_abstract: Full-image dependencies provide useful contextual information to benefit visual understanding problems. In this work, we propose a Criss-Cross Network (CCNet) for obtaining such contextual information in a more effective and efficient way. Concretely, for each pixel, a novel criss-cross attention module in CCNet harvests the contextual information of all the pixels on its criss-cross path. By taking a further recurrent operation, each pixel can finally capture the full-image dependencies from all pixels. Overall, CCNet is with the following merits: 1) GPU memory friendly. Compared with the non-local block, the proposed recurrent criss-cross attention module requires 11x less GPU memory usage. 2) High computational efficiency. The recurrent criss-cross attention significantly reduces FLOPs by about 85% of the non-local block in computing full-image dependencies. 3) The state-of-the-art performance. We conduct extensive experiments on popular semantic segmentation benchmarks including Cityscapes, ADE20K, and instance segmentation benchmark COCO. In particular, our CCNet achieves the mIoU score of 81.4 and 45.22 on Cityscapes test set and ADE20K validation set, respectively, which are the new state-of-the-art results. The source code is available at https://github. com/speedinghzl/CCNet.

She also leads the **High Performance Architecture (HPArch) research group** and serves as co-director of the **Center for Research into Novel Computing Hierarchies (CRNCH)**. Her primary research focuses on designing <u>high-performance, energy-efficient computer architectures</u>, with a particular emphasis on the intersection of computer architecture, compilers, and runtime systems. Dr. Kim's work specifically addresses challenges in <u>heterogeneous architectures</u>, such as GPUs and near-data processing.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Kim specializes in a broad array of research areas within computer systems. Her expertise includes **Computer Architecture**, **Compiler Design**, and the intricate **interaction between programmers, compilers, and architectures**. She conducts significant work in *Parallel Computing* and *GPU Computing*, encompassing areas like *performance modeling and analysis*, *memory systems*, and *heterogeneous computing*. Additionally, her research extends to cutting-edge fields such as **Near-Memory Computing**, **Deep Learning Hardware**, and **Hardware Security**. Her studies also delve into *memory bandwidth*, *cache mechanisms*, *multithreading*, and *operating systems* in the context of high-performance and embedded systems.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Kim developed foundational **analytical models for GPU architectures**, which provided crucial insights into performance bottlenecks and significantly advanced the optimization of applications on these massively parallel processors. This work also included integrated power and performance models, contributing to the design of more energy-efficient GPUs.
*   She made significant contributions to **exploiting parallelism on heterogeneous multiprocessors** through adaptive mapping techniques. This research aimed to automate the complex process of efficiently assigning computations to diverse processing elements, thereby enhancing overall system performance and energy efficiency by reducing manual programming effort and adapting dynamically to runtime conditions.
*   Her work extends to the critical area of **processing-in-memory (PIM)** and **hardware security**. Through projects like enabling instruction-level PIM offloading in graph computing frameworks and exploring transparent hardware management of stacked DRAM, she has tackled the "memory wall" problem for data-intensive applications. paper_abstract: This pictorial presents our material-driven inquiry into carbon-coated paper and kirigami structures. We investigated two variations of this paper and their affordances for tangible interaction; particularly their electrical, haptic, and visual aspects when shaped into three-dimensional forms through cutting, folding, and bending. Through this exploration, we uncovered distinct affordances between the two paper types for sensing folds and bends, due to differences in their material compositions. paper_abstract: In this paper we introduce a new algorithm for image and video texture synthesis. In our approach, patch regions from a sample image or video are transformed and copied to the output and then stitched together along optimal seams to generate a new (and typically larger) output. In contrast to other techniques, the size of the patch is not chosen a-priori, but instead a graph cut technique is used to determine the optimal patch region for any given offset between the input and output texture. Unlike dynamic programming, our graph cut technique for seam optimization is applicable in any dimension. We specifically explore it in 2D and 3D to perform video texture synthesis in addition to regular image synthesis. We present approximative offset search techniques that work well in conjunction with the presented patch size optimization. We show results for synthesizing regular, random, and natural images and videos. We …

researcher_keywords: Machine Learning, Game Theory, Sequential Decision Making
paper_abstract: We propose studying GAN training dynamics as regret minimization, which is in contrast to the popular view that there is consistent minimization of a divergence between real and generated distributions. We analyze the convergence of GAN training from this new point of view to understand why mode collapse happens. We hypothesize the existence of undesirable local equilibria in this non-convex game to be responsible for mode collapse. We observe that these local equilibria often exhibit sharp gradients of the discriminator function around some real data points. We demonstrate that these degenerate local equilibria can be avoided with a gradient penalty scheme called DRAGAN. We show that DRAGAN enables faster training, achieves improved stability with fewer mode collapses, and leads to generator networks with better modeling performance across a variety of architectures and objective functions.

researcher_keywords: Programming Languages, Static Analysis, Compilers, Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Recent years have witnessed a resurgence of interest in video summarization. However, one of the main obstacles to the research on video summarization is the user subjectivity---users have various preferences over the summaries. The subjectiveness causes at least two problems. First, no single video summarizer fits all users unless it interacts with and adapts to the individual users. Second, it is very challenging to evaluate the performance of a video summarizer. To tackle the first problem, we explore the recently proposed query-focused video summarization which introduces user preferences in the form of text queries about the video into the summarization process. We propose a memory network parameterized sequential determinantal point process in order to attend the user query onto different video frames and shots. To address the second challenge, we contend that a good evaluation metric for video summarization should focus on the semantic information that humans can perceive rather than the visual features or temporal overlaps. To this end, we collect dense per-video-shot concept annotations, compile a new dataset, and suggest an efficient evaluation method defined upon the concept annotations. We conduct extensive experiments contrasting our video summarizer to existing ones and present detailed analyses about the dataset and the new evaluation method.

paper_abstract: Independence is key to a successful transition to adulthood for individuals with autism. Social support is a crucial factor for achieving adaptive self-help life skills. In this paper we describe the results of a formative design exercise with young adults with autism and their caregivers to uncover opportunities for social networks to promote independence and facilitate coordination. We propose the concept of SocialMirror, a device connected to an online social network that allows the young adult to seek advice from a trusted and responsive network of family, friends and professionals. Focus group discussions reveal the potential for SocialMirror to increase motivation to learn everyday life skills among young adults with autism and to foster collaboration among a distributed care network. We present design considerations to leverage a small trusted network that balances quick response with safeguards for privacy and …

Her primary research focuses on **Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)** and **Computer-Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW)**, with a distinct emphasis on <u>health and wellbeing</u>. Dr. Kim's work investigates the design and evaluation of social and health information systems aimed at promoting <u>diversity, advocacy, and empathy</u>, particularly for neurodiverse individuals and their communities.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Kim specializes in a diverse range of research areas, including **Human-Computer Interaction**, **Computer-Supported Cooperative Work**, and the design of **Assistive Technologies**. Her work extensively covers *Autism Spectrum Disorder Research*, **Social Computing**, and the application of *Virtual Reality in Education and Training*. Additionally, her expertise spans **Health Informatics**, **Data Visualization and Analytics**, *Human-Robot Interaction*, and **Accessibility and Inclusive Design**. Her recent contributions also highlight the use of <u>Large Language Models (LLMs)</u> and <u>AI-driven solutions</u> in various health and social contexts.

paper_abstract: One of the most expensive and time-consuming components of the debugging process is locating the errors or faults. To locate faults, developers must identify statements involved in failures and select suspicious statements that might contain faults. This paper presents a new technique that uses visualization to assist with these tasks. The technique uses color to visually map the participation of each program statement in the outcome of the execution of the program with a test suite, consisting of both passed and failed test cases. Based on this visual mapping, a user can inspect the statements in the program, identify statements involved in failures, and locate potentially faulty statements. The paper also describes a prototype tool that implements our technique along with a set of empirical studies that use the tool for evaluation of the technique. ## Notable Works

affiliation: Associate Professor of International Relations, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: International security, cybersecurity, military power, evolution
paper_abstract: Stuxnet, the computer worm which disrupted Iranian nuclear enrichment in 2010, is the first instance of a computer network attack known to cause physical damage across international boundaries. Some have described Stuxnet as the harbinger of a new form of warfare that threatens even the strongest military powers. The influential but largely untested Cyber Revolution thesis holds that the internet gives militarily weaker actors asymmetric advantages, that offense is becoming easier while defense is growing harder, and that the attacker's anonymity undermines deterrence. However, the empirical facts of Stuxnet support an opposite interpretation; cyber capabilities can marginally enhance the power of stronger over weaker actors, the complexity of weaponization makes cyber offense less easy and defense more feasible than generally appreciated, and cyber options are most attractive when deterrence is intact …
