His career trajectory highlights a consistent focus on interdisciplinary research that bridges the fields of cognitive science, neuroscience, and education, with a recent expansion into the cognitive implications of artificial intelligence.

researcher_keywords: robotics, computer graphics, machine learning
paper_abstract: Model-free deep reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms have been successfully applied to a range of challenging sequential decision making and control tasks. However, these methods typically suffer from two major challenges: high sample complexity and brittleness to hyperparameters. Both of these challenges limit the applicability of such methods to real-world domains. In this paper, we describe Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), our recently introduced off-policy actor-critic algorithm based on the maximum entropy RL framework. In this framework, the actor aims to simultaneously maximize expected return and entropy. That is, to succeed at the task while acting as randomly as possible. We extend SAC to incorporate a number of modifications that accelerate training and improve stability with respect to the hyperparameters, including a constrained formulation that automatically tunes the temperature hyperparameter. We systematically evaluate SAC on a range of benchmark tasks, as well as real-world challenging tasks such as locomotion for a quadrupedal robot and robotic manipulation with a dexterous hand. With these improvements, SAC achieves state-of-the-art performance, outperforming prior on-policy and off-policy methods in sample-efficiency and asymptotic performance. Furthermore, we demonstrate that, in contrast to other off-policy algorithms, our approach is very stable, achieving similar performance across different random seeds. These results suggest that SAC is a promising candidate for learning in real-world robotics tasks.

affiliation: Professor of Computer Science, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Database Systems
paper_abstract: Mining for association rules between items in a large database of sales transactions has been described as an important database mining problem. In this paper we present an e cient algorithm for mining association rules that is fundamentally di erent from known algorithms. Compared to the previous algorithms, our algorithm reduces both CPU and I/O overheads. In our experimental study it was found that for large databases, the CPU overhead was reduced by as much as a factor of seven and I/O was reduced by almost an order of magnitude. Hence this algorithm is especially suitable for very large size databases. The algorithm is also ideally suited for parallelization. We have performed extensive experiments and compared the performance of the algorithm with one of the best existing algorithms.

Navathe** is a *Professor Emeritus* in the **College of Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*, having recently transitioned into this role after 34 years of service to the institution and a distinguished 50-year academic career. He founded the **Research Group in Database Systems** at Georgia Tech, where his primary research has focused on <u>database modeling, design, and integration</u>. Dr. Navathe's work particularly emphasizes these areas within the context of **emerging applications** such as engineering design, biological (human genome) databases, document and text databases, and collaborative environments. His ongoing interests also encompass **knowledge representation**, **data mining and knowledge discovery**, and the development of *tools and methodologies for information system design*, as well as innovative *visualization and user interfaces for enhanced information retrieval*.

## Research Areas

Dr. Navathe specializes in a comprehensive range of research areas within computer science, prominently including **Database Systems**, **Data Mining**, **Schema Integration**, **Database Design**, **Data Modeling**, and **Information Systems Security**. His expertise also extends to **Temporal Databases**, **Distributed Databases**, **Query Processing**, and **Information Retrieval**. He has made significant contributions to *object-oriented and heterogeneous data management*, alongside *design tools and methodologies* applicable to legacy and engineering databases.

*   Dr. Navathe is widely recognized as the co-author of the seminal textbook, ***Fundamentals of Database Systems***, which has become a global standard in computer science education. First published in 1989 and now in its 7th edition, this comprehensive work has been translated into 12 languages, profoundly shaping the academic journey of countless students and serving as a critical resource for database professionals worldwide.
*   He has made pioneering contributions to **database modeling and design**, developing robust methodologies for **database schema integration** and conceptual database design, including *vertical partitioning algorithms*. These advancements have significantly enhanced the efficiency and organization of large database systems, facilitating unified data representation across diverse applications.
*   His research in **data mining** has led to the development of efficient algorithms for discovering *association rules* and *strong negative associations* in large customer transaction databases, providing critical insights for business intelligence and decision-making by identifying important patterns within vast datasets.

## Academic Background

He continued his graduate studies in the United States, receiving an **M.S. in Computer and Information Science** from *Ohio State University* in 1970 and a **Ph.D. in Industrial and Operations Engineering** from the *University of Michigan* in 1976. Before joining **Georgia Tech** in 1990, he held assistant professor positions at *New York University* and the *University of Florida*.

Navathe Distinguished Lecture Series</u>" at Georgia Tech. researcher_keywords: Feminist HCI, Humanistic Computing, Sustainability, Women’s Health, Design Research
paper_abstract: Feminism is a natural ally to interaction design, due to its central commitments to issues such as agency, fulfillment, identity, equity, empowerment, and social justice. In this paper, I summarize the state of the art of feminism in HCI and propose ways to build on existing successes to more robustly integrate feminism into interaction design research and practice. I explore the productive role of feminism in analogous fields, such as industrial design, architecture, and game design. I introduce examples of feminist interaction design already in the field. Finally, I propose a set of femi-nist interaction design qualities intended to support design and evaluation processes directly as they unfold.

## Research Areas

A significant portion of his research investigates the exploitation of accessibility features and fingerprint APIs in Android, the development of robust control-flow integrity mechanisms, and strategies for software debloating to reduce attack surfaces.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Chung's research has critically examined <u>fundamental vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems</u>, demonstrating how seemingly benign applications can be exploited for malicious purposes (e.g., "Jekyll on {iOS}"), how UI elements can be hijacked to mislead users ("Cloak and Dagger"), and how physical charging mechanisms can be leveraged for malware injection ("Mactans"). These contributions have raised significant awareness regarding mobile device security, influencing the development of stronger defenses against sophisticated attacks.
*   He has made important strides in **enhancing software resilience** against control-hijacking attacks through his work on methods like "ASLR-Guard" and "Enforcing unique code target property for control-flow integrity," which aim to ensure that control-flow transfers only occur to legitimate targets. *   Dr. Chung has also developed innovative solutions in **privacy and authentication**, including systems like "rtCaptcha" for real-time liveness detection in facial/voice-based authentication and "Fuzzy labeled private set intersection" for private biometric search. His research further highlights privacy leakage risks in personalized mobile in-app advertisements and proposes "Mimesis Aegis" as a system-level approach to data privacy on public clouds, providing crucial advancements for securing personal data in an increasingly interconnected world.

## Academic Background

His extensive publication record, with several highly cited papers, underscores his significant contributions to the academic and professional communities in computer and mobile security. His trajectory reflects a dedicated focus on practical security challenges and the development of impactful defensive mechanisms.

affiliation: Associate Professor, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Robotics, Artificial Intelligence
paper_abstract: We present a comprehensive survey of robot Learning from Demonstration (LfD), a technique that develops policies from example state to action mappings. We introduce the LfD design choices in terms of demonstrator, problem space, policy derivation and performance, and contribute the foundations for a structure in which to categorize LfD research. Specifically, we analyze and categorize the multiple ways in which examples are gathered, ranging from teleoperation to imitation, as well as the various techniques for policy derivation, including matching functions, dynamics models and plans. To conclude we discuss LfD limitations and related promising areas for future research.

His primary research centers on the intersection of <u>high-performance computing and computational biology</u>, with a strong emphasis on data science and bioinformatics. He is also affiliated with the **School of Computational Science and Engineering**, where he previously served as Interim Chair.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Aluru specializes in a diverse range of computational fields, including **high-performance computing**, **data science**, **bioinformatics**, and **systems biology**. His work spans <u>computational genomics</u>, *combinatorial scientific computing*, and the design and analysis of <u>advanced algorithms</u>. Currently, his group is focused on developing bioinformatics methods for *next-generation sequencing data analysis*, including error correction and genome assembly, as well as the construction of and alignments to <u>genome graphs</u>, and network methods for **single-cell biology**.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Aluru has made significant contributions to the *assembly and analysis of complex plant genomes*, including pioneering the **sequencing of the 2.3-gigabase maize genome**, which greatly advanced the understanding of this important crop plant. This work involved developing new parallel methods for handling massive genomic datasets.
*   He developed **FastANI**, a high-throughput method that efficiently estimates Average Nucleotide Identity (ANI) for *90,000 prokaryotic genomes*, revealing <u>clear species boundaries</u> and facilitating high-resolution taxonomic analysis.
*   His research also includes fundamental advancements in <u>string algorithms</u>, such as the *space-efficient linear time construction of suffix arrays* and the development of parallel methods for <u>biological sequence comparison and alignment</u>, which are crucial for various applications in pattern matching and computational biology.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Aluru earned his **B.Tech in computer science** from the *Indian Institute of Technology Madras* in 1989, followed by his **M.S. (1991)** and **Ph.D. (1994)** in computer science from *Iowa State University*. Before joining Georgia Tech in 2013, he held faculty positions at Syracuse University, New Mexico State University, and Iowa State University, where he also held endowed professorships.

He is a highly recognized leader in his field, having been appointed a **Regents' Professor** by the University System of Georgia in 2023. His extensive accolades include being named a *Fellow of the IEEE (2010), AAAS (2010), ACM (2020), and SIAM (2020)*. Notably, he is the recipient of the **2025 IEEE Computer Society Charles Babbage Award** for his pioneering contributions to parallel computing and computational biology. He also served as Executive Director of the **Institute for Data Engineering and Science (IDEaS)** at Georgia Tech from 2019 to 2024 and co-led the NSF South Big Data Regional Innovation Hub.

affiliation: Assistant Professor, Computer Science, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: active learning, experiment design, data-centric machine learning
paper_abstract: We seek to learn models that we can interact with using high-level concepts: if the model did not think there was a bone spur in the x-ray, would it still predict severe arthritis? State-of-the-art models today do not typically support the manipulation of concepts like" the existence of bone spurs", as they are trained end-to-end to go directly from raw input (eg, pixels) to output (eg, arthritis severity). We revisit the classic idea of first predicting concepts that are provided at training time, and then using these concepts to predict the label. By construction, we can intervene on these concept bottleneck models by editing their predicted concept values and propagating these changes to the final prediction. On x-ray grading and bird identification, concept bottleneck models achieve competitive accuracy with standard end-to-end models, while enabling interpretation in terms of high-level clinical concepts (" bone spurs") or bird attributes (" wing color"). These models also allow for richer human-model interaction: accuracy improves significantly if we can correct model mistakes on concepts at test time.

## Overview

He also explores various facets of _data curation_, _dataset benchmarking_, and _model evaluation_ to improve the robustness and performance of ML systems. Furthermore, his research extends to understanding _statistical aspects of data algorithms_, such as noise and domain shifts, and working with _probabilistic graphical models_ and _latent variable models_.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Mussmann has contributed to the development of models that facilitate interaction with **high-level concepts**, allowing users to manipulate abstract notions within a model's predictions. This work enables a deeper understanding and querying of how models arrive at their conclusions, moving beyond direct input-output mapping.
*   He played a key role in creating a **testbed for multimodal dataset experiments**, which is instrumental in the design and curation of next-generation multimodal datasets. His career trajectory highlights a consistent focus on _advancing machine learning through data-centric innovations_.

affiliation: Assistant Professor, Computer Science, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Formal methods, Programming languages, Artificial intelligence
paper_abstract: We study the problem of learning control policies for complex tasks given by logical specifications. Recent approaches automatically generate a reward function from a given specification and use a suitable reinforcement learning algorithm to learn a policy that maximizes the expected reward. These approaches, however, scale poorly to complex tasks that require high-level planning. In this work, we develop a compositional learning approach, called DIRL, that interleaves high-level planning and reinforcement learning. First, DIRL encodes the specification as an abstract graph; intuitively, vertices and edges of the graph correspond to regions of the state space and simpler sub-tasks, respectively. Our approach then incorporates reinforcement learning to learn neural network policies for each edge (sub-task) within a Dijkstra-style planning algorithm to compute a high-level plan in the graph. An evaluation of the proposed approach on a set of challenging control benchmarks with continuous state and action spaces demonstrates that it outperforms state-of-the-art baselines.

## Research Areas

Dr. Bansal specializes in a diverse array of interconnected research areas, encompassing **formal methods**, **programming languages**, and **artificial intelligence**. ## Research Areas

## Overview

He also serves as the <u>Director of the GTS3: System Software and Security Center</u>. Additionally, Dr. Kim holds the position of *Corporate Vice President* at **Samsung Electronics**. His primary research focuses on building <u>principled and secure computing systems</u>, developing advanced tools for intrusion detection, and enabling effective system recovery from cyberattacks without extensive manual intervention.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Kim specializes in a comprehensive range of research areas, predominantly centered on **Systems Security**, **Operating Systems**, and **Trusted Execution Environments**. His expertise extends to *Programming Languages, Distributed Systems, Fuzzing, Memory Safety, File Systems, Computer Architecture, Program Analysis, Cloud Security,* and *Intrusion Detection and Prevention*. He is particularly known for his contributions to enhancing the security of operating systems and other critical system components against sophisticated attacks.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Kim has made significant contributions to securing **Intel Software Guard Extensions (SGX)**, a hardware-based trusted execution environment. His research has unveiled vulnerabilities like page-fault-based attacks and developed countermeasures such as *T-SGX* and *SGX-shield*, which improve the isolation and randomization of SGX enclaves, making secure computation more robust against various side-channel and memory corruption attacks.
*   He is a pioneer in the field of **fuzzing**, particularly with the development of *QSYM*, a practical concolic execution engine tailored for hybrid fuzzing. This work, alongside his research on designing new operating primitives to improve fuzzing performance, has drastically enhanced the ability to automatically discover critical bugs and security vulnerabilities in complex real-world software and kernel file systems.
*   His research also addresses fundamental challenges in **kernel security and memory safety**, including groundbreaking work on *breaking and fixing Kernel Address Space Layout Randomization (KASLR)* with Intel TSX, and developing techniques like "Preventing Use-after-free with Dangling Pointers Nullification" and *HDFI (Hardware-assisted data-flow isolation)*. These efforts provide robust defenses against prevalent memory corruption exploits that often underpin severe cyberattacks.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Kim earned his **Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science** from the *Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)* in 2014, where he specialized in systems security under the guidance of **Professors Nickolai Zeldovich** and **Frans Kaashoek**. He also received his *Master of Science (SM)* from MIT in 2011. Prior to his graduate studies, he completed his bachelor's degrees in both **Computer Science** and **Electrical Engineering** from the *Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology (KAIST)* in 2009, graduating *summa cum laude*.

He joined *Georgia Tech* in 2014 as an Assistant Professor, rising to the rank of Associate Professor in 2019 and then Full Professor in 2022. Dr. Kim has received numerous accolades, including the **2015 Internet Defense Prize from USENIX and Facebook**, the **NSF CAREER Award in 2018** for his fuzzing research, and a **Google Research Award in 2019**. He was also a finalist in the inaugural DARPA Cyber Grand Challenge with Team Disekt and later achieved first place in the DARPA AIxCC as part of Team Atlanta. His career trajectory highlights a sustained commitment to advancing the frontiers of computer systems security.

This article documents themes found in research regarding the Digital Divide from the perspective of school technology integration for children in the U.S. school systems: frequency of use, the differences in students’ educational technology experiences, and teacher professional development. paper_abstract: Neural networks are increasingly employed in safety-critical domains. This has prompted interest in verifying or certifying logically encoded properties of neural networks. Prior work has largely focused on checking existential properties, wherein the goal is to check whether there exists any input that violates a given property of interest. However, neural network training is a stochastic process, and many questions arising in their analysis require probabilistic and quantitative reasoning, i.e., estimating how many inputs satisfy a given property. To this end, our paper proposes a novel and principled framework to quantitative verification of logical properties specified over neural networks. Our framework is the first to provide PAC-style soundness guarantees, in that its quantitative estimates are within a controllable and bounded error from the true count. We instantiate our algorithmic framework by building a prototype tool …

## Overview

**Teodora Baluta** is currently an *Assistant Professor* in the **School of Cybersecurity and Privacy** within the **College of Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*, having joined in September 2024. Her primary research is dedicated to conducting <u>rigorous security analyses for machine learning (ML) systems</u>, encompassing foundational aspects such as defining security, developing abstractions, and establishing sound procedures for statistical verifiability. She investigates the algorithms and datasets used to train new AI tools to assess their security in both theory and practice, with a particular focus on whether generative AI outputs are misusing data or producing content based on stolen information. Dr. Baluta is driven by algorithmic problems that also possess significant practical relevance.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Baluta specializes in a comprehensive range of research areas at the intersection of security and artificial intelligence. Her key areas of expertise include **Security and Privacy**, **Machine Learning Security**, and the **Formal Verification of Machine Learning Systems**, particularly focusing on quantitative verification for neural networks. She also conducts extensive work in *Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning*, including applications to graph networks and federated clustering, and researches various aspects of *Adversarial Machine Learning*. Additionally, her interests span **Program Synthesis**, *Causal Inference in AI* for understanding model behavior and improving SAT solving, and emerging fields like **Machine Unlearning** in large language models and **Model Provenance Testing** for LLMs.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Baluta has developed frameworks for <u>scalable quantitative verification of deep neural networks</u>, providing crucial formal guarantees about their trustworthiness and addressing their increasing deployment in safety-critical domains. This work offers sound procedures for statistically verifying both black-box and white-box ML systems.
*   Her research has established <u>rigorous security analyses for machine learning systems</u> by providing provable methods to determine if stochastic gradient descent (SGD) executions are unforgeable. This breakthrough offers a concrete test for collision resistance in training steps, which is vital for resolving intellectual property disputes in the field. She also introduced a causal model for SGD to meticulously analyze the intricate connection between model generalization and tests for memorization in the context of membership inference attacks.
*   She has made significant contributions to **differential privacy for graph networks** and **private hierarchical clustering in federated environments**, enabling analytics on sensitive, distributed data while preserving user privacy. Furthermore, her work extends to **user-customizable transpilation of scripting languages** and enhancing the efficiency of SAT solving through novel causal reasoning techniques.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Baluta earned her **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from the *National University of Singapore (NUS)* from 2017 to 2024, where she was advised by **Dr. Prateek Saxena** and **Dr. Kuldeep S. Meel**. Prior to her doctoral studies, she completed her **M.Sc. in Computer Science** (2014-2016) and **B.Sc. in Computer Science** (2010-2014) at *Politehnica University of Bucharest, Romania*. Her exceptional academic performance has been recognized through numerous accolades, including the **EECS Rising Stars award** from Georgia Tech in 2023, the *Google PhD Fellowship* (2021-2023), and the *Dean's Graduate Research Excellence Award* from NUS in 2023. She also served as a research intern at **Google Brain**, contributing to the Learning for Code team. Dr. Baluta's career trajectory showcases a strong dedication to the intersection of computer security and machine learning, with a consistent focus on fundamental algorithmic challenges and their practical implications.

## Overview

**Dr. Thad Starner** is a *Professor of Computing* in the **School of Interactive Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. He serves as the founder and director of the **Contextual Computing Group**, where his primary research centers on integrating wearable and ubiquitous computing technologies with advancements in Artificial Intelligence, pattern recognition, and human-computer interaction. A strong advocate for continuous-access, everyday-use systems, Dr. Starner has notably worn his own customized wearable computer continuously since 1993, pioneering the practical application of these technologies. His work profoundly impacts the development of augmented realities and intelligent agents that enhance human capabilities and interactions with the environment.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Starner specializes in a comprehensive array of research domains, with a foundational emphasis on **Wearable Computing** and **Artificial Intelligence**. His expertise spans across *Augmented Reality*, **Human Computer Interaction (HCI)**, *Computer Vision*, **Ubiquitous Computing**, and *Machine Learning*.

Beyond these core areas, his work extends to **Sensor Networks**, *Mobile Computing*, and *Information Retrieval*, exploring how these technologies can create intelligent, context-aware systems. More recently, his research includes **Animal Computer Interaction**, developing wearable devices to facilitate communication with working dogs and wild dolphins, and **assistive technologies** for the Deaf community and individuals with ALS, focusing on innovative methods for sign language recognition and brain-computer interfaces.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Starner is a recognized pioneer in **wearable computing** and **augmented reality**, having coined the term "augmented reality" in 1990 and continuously wearing his own system since 1993. His foundational work has significantly influenced the development of ubiquitous computing, leading to prototypes and patents for mobile instant messaging, e-mail, and gesture-based interfaces that foreshadowed many modern commonplace devices and services. He also served as a Technical Lead/Manager on **Google's Glass** project, a landmark in head-mounted display technology.

*   His contributions to **assistive technology** are particularly impactful, notably in the field of **American Sign Language (ASL) recognition**. Dr. Starner has developed real-time ASL recognition systems using computer vision and Hidden Markov Models, creating tools like the *CopyCat game* to assist deaf children in acquiring language skills. His research also addresses communication challenges for individuals with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) through the development of brain-computer interfaces that interpret attempted sign language movements.

*   Dr. Starner's innovative research includes the discovery and development of **Passive Haptic Learning (PHL)** and **Passive Haptic Rehabilitation**. This pioneering work enables wearable computer users to learn complex manual skills, such as playing the piano or typing Braille, with minimal conscious attention. Furthermore, this research has been applied to rehabilitation, providing methods for stroke patients to regain hand function and dexterity.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Starner earned his **B.S. in Brain and Cognitive Science** and **B.S. in Computer Science** in 1991 from the *Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)*, where he also completed his **M.S. in Media Arts and Science** and later his **Ph.D. in Media Arts and Sciences** in 1999 from the *MIT Media Laboratory*. His doctoral research, "Wearable Computing and Contextual Awareness," explored pattern recognition and the utility of wearable computing for tasks such as recognizing American Sign Language hand motions.

His career trajectory includes significant roles as a **Professor of Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology* and as a Technical Lead/Manager on **Google's Glass** project. Dr. Starner is a co-founder of the *IEEE International Symposium on Wearable Computers (ISWC)* and was among the initial members of the *MIT Wearable Computing Project*. In recognition of his profound contributions and leadership in the wearable computing research community, he was named an **ACM Fellow in 2024** and was elected to the **CHI Academy in 2017**. He has also been a finalist for the Lemelson-MIT Prize for inventorship and the White House's Champions of Change for his work on Deaf education.

researcher_keywords: Computational Behavior Analysis, Activity Recognition, Ubiquitous Computing, Health, Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) in ubiquitous computing is beginning to adopt deep learning to substitute for well-established analysis techniques that rely on hand-crafted feature extraction and classification techniques. From these isolated applications of custom deep architectures it is, however, difficult to gain an overview of their suitability for problems ranging from the recognition of manipulative gestures to the segmentation and identification of physical activities like running or ascending stairs. In this paper we rigorously explore deep, convolutional, and recurrent approaches across three representative datasets that contain movement data captured with wearable sensors. We describe how to train recurrent approaches in this setting, introduce a novel regularisation approach, and illustrate how they outperform the state-of-the-art on a large benchmark dataset. Across thousands of recognition experiments with randomly sampled model configurations we investigate the suitability of each model for different tasks in HAR, explore the impact of hyperparameters using the fANOVA framework, and provide guidelines for the practitioner who wants to apply deep learning in their problem setting.

## Overview

**Thomas Ploetz** is currently a *Professor of Computing* and the *Associate Chair of Graduate Studies* in the **School of Interactive Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. He also serves as the *Chief AI Officer* at **Parmonic Inc.** His primary research agenda focuses on **applied machine learning** for developing innovative sensor data analysis methods and systems for real-world applications, with a strong emphasis on <u>computational behavior analysis</u>. Dr. Ploetz's work aims to create automated and objective behavior assessments in naturalistic environments, particularly impacting people's lives through "in the wild" deployments in health-related scenarios.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Ploetz specializes in a diverse range of research areas, prominently including **Computational Behavior Analysis**, **Activity Recognition**, and **Ubiquitous Computing**. His expertise spans **Machine Learning**, particularly in the context of *Human Activity Recognition (HAR)* using wearable devices and *Biomedical Signal Processing*.

He also focuses on **Health Monitoring** and **Health Analytics**, applying sensor data analysis to assess physical activity and detect health and welfare compromises. His work further extends to *Skill Assessment*, *Animal Behavior Analysis*, *Context Awareness*, *Assistive Technology*, and *Sequential Data Analysis*.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Ploetz has significantly advanced **human activity recognition** through the development of *deep, convolutional, and recurrent models* for wearable sensors. His work has enabled robust and generalized predictive models for understanding human activities in real-life settings, moving beyond traditional hand-crafted features to more powerful deep learning approaches, which is crucial for applications in health monitoring and personalized feedback.
*   His research has provided crucial contributions to the **early detection of health and welfare compromises** using automated behavioral analysis. This includes devising systems for the automated detection of behavioral changes in pigs for health monitoring and developing methods for objective disease state assessment in neurological conditions like *Parkinson's Disease* and *stroke recovery* in naturalistic home environments. These advancements aim to offer timely interventions and improve patient management.
*   He has also pioneered methods for **objective skill assessment** from sensor data, transcending basic activity identification to evaluate the quality of human movements. This is exemplified by systems like *GymSkill* and *ClimbAX*, which provide individualized and personalized feedback on physical exercises and climbing performance, contributing to improved training quality and user engagement.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Ploetz earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science**, specializing in *Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning research*, from **Bielefeld University** in Germany.

His career trajectory includes roles as a *Senior Researcher* at **Dortmund University of Technology** and an academic at **Newcastle University** in the U.K., where he was a *Reader* (Associate Professor) for Computational Behavior Analysis affiliated with Open Lab. He joined the *Georgia Institute of Technology* in **2017** as a Professor, having previously been a Research Fellow there from 2011 to 2012. He leads the **Computational Behavioral Analysis Lab** at Georgia Tech.

paper_abstract: BACKGROUNDNetworks typically provide multiple potential transmis sion paths from a source to a destination. For example, com munication between a personal computer in Boston and a server in Los Angeles may be routed over a ten different (and equally reasonable) paths depending upon how the network is configured and the current traffic loading on each link among the intervening nodes. Routing on the Internet is typically done using a single path selected from among multiple avail able paths with the chosen path determined by various net work administrators. The motivation behind such “ad hoc'routing is to simplify network management, reduce the need to update routing tables at the various nodes, etc., with the overall goal being more efficient network utilization. ## Overview

**Thomas Martin Conte**, known as Tom Conte, currently serves as the *Associate Dean for Research* in the **College of Computing** at the Georgia Institute of Technology, where he also holds a joint appointment as a *Professor* in both the **Schools of Computer Science** and **Electrical & Computer Engineering**. His primary research focuses on <u>computer architecture and compiler optimization</u>, with a particular emphasis on novel computing paradigms beyond traditional silicon-based approaches and exploring post-Moore era architectures. Additionally, he was the founding director of Georgia Tech's **Center for Research into Novel Computing Hierarchies (CRNCH)**. He is also recognized for his leadership within the IEEE, having served as the **2015 President of the IEEE Computer Society** and co-founding the <u>IEEE Rebooting Computing Initiative</u> in 2012.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Conte's expertise spans a comprehensive range of topics within computer systems, including **Computer Architecture**, **Compilers**, and **Computer Performance Evaluation**. His work delves into *Compilers and Optimization*, focusing on instruction-level parallelism (ILP) and back-end compiler code generation, alongside deep exploration of *Performance Analysis and Modeling*. Furthermore, his research encompasses **Microarchitecture Design**, **Parallel Processing and Multicore Systems**, **Embedded Systems Design**, and *Hardware-Software Co-design*. He also contributes significantly to the fields of **Computer Simulation and Benchmarking** and *Reconfigurable Computing*, with a strong emphasis on designing systems for future high-performance and energy-efficient computing.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Conte has made significant contributions to the field of **computer performance evaluation and simulation**, developing methodologies and tools that allow for the systematic analysis and optimization of computer architectures. This work has been crucial in understanding how various design choices impact processor and memory system performance, leading to more efficient and powerful computing systems.
*   He is also well-regarded for his advancements in **compiler optimization and instruction-level parallelism (ILP)**, particularly in designing innovative instruction fetch mechanisms and scheduling algorithms for wide-issue processors. His research has enhanced how compilers generate code, improving the utilization of hardware resources and boosting the execution speed of software on high-performance microprocessors.
*   A major recent undertaking includes his role in co-founding the **IEEE Rebooting Computing Initiative** and his efforts in transitioning the *International Technology Roadmap for Semiconductors* into the **International Roadmap for Devices and Systems (IRDS)** under IEEE. This initiative addresses the fundamental challenges facing the future of computing beyond the limits of Moore's Law, fostering research into entirely new computing paradigms and technologies to sustain progress in the field.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Conte earned his **Bachelor of Electrical Engineering** from the *University of Delaware in 1986*, followed by his **Master of Science** and **Doctor of Philosophy** degrees in *Electrical Engineering from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1988 and 1992, respectively*. He began his academic career at the *University of South Carolina* before moving to *North Carolina State University*, where he advanced to **Full Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering** and directed the **Center for Embedded Systems Research**.

In 2008, he joined Georgia Tech, assuming his current roles. His contributions have been recognized with the **National Science Foundation Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Award** in 1996 and the *Young Alumni Achievement Award* from the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 2004. He is also an **IEEE Fellow**, a testament to his extensive impact on computer architecture, compiler code generation, and performance evaluation. His research has received support from various prestigious organizations, including DARPA, IBM, Intel, NASA, and the National Science Foundation.

affiliation: Professor of Computer Science, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: embedded and pervasive systems, parallel and distributed systems, computer architecture, operating systems
paper_abstract: The ubiquitous deployment of mobile and sensor devices is creating a new environment, namely the Internet of Things(IoT), that enables a wide range of future Internet applications. In this work, we present Mobile Fog, a high level programming model for the future Internet applications that are geospatially distributed, large-scale, and latency-sensitive. We analyze use cases for the programming model with camera network and connected vehicle applications to show the efficacy of Mobile Fog. We also evaluate application performance through simulation.

## Overview

**Umakishore Ramachandran** is a *Professor* in the **School of Computer Science** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. His primary research centers on the <u>architectural design, programming, and analysis of parallel and distributed systems</u>. Currently, he spearheads projects focused on achieving **large-scale situation awareness** through distributed camera networks and multi-modal sensing, with direct applications in areas such as surveillance and connected vehicles. He also leads a planning grant exploring **Edge Computing** solutions to deliver smart services to underserved urban communities.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Ramachandran specializes in a comprehensive array of research domains, including **embedded and pervasive systems**, **parallel and distributed systems**, **computer architecture**, and **operating systems**. His work extensively covers **Fog Computing**, the **Internet of Things (IoT)**, **Middleware**, **Data Fusion**, and **Embedded Systems**. A significant portion of his research addresses the development of *geo-distributed, large-scale, and latency-sensitive applications* for the IoT, alongside contributions to distributed operating systems and distributed shared memory.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Ramachandran developed the **Mobile Fog programming model**, a high-level framework designed for large-scale, geo-spatially distributed, and latency-sensitive applications within the Internet of Things. This model demonstrated its effectiveness in critical use cases such as camera networks and connected vehicle applications, significantly advancing the practical implementation of Fog Computing paradigms.
*   He made seminal contributions to the **Clouds distributed operating system**, where he pioneered the integration of Distributed Shared Memory (DSM). This work introduced an innovative object-thread model, enhancing the structure of distributed operating systems and substantially improving the efficiency of memory management in complex distributed environments.
*   A notable achievement in his educational leadership is his role in defining and implementing the curriculum for *Georgia Tech's online MS in Computer Science (OMSCS) program*. This initiative leveraged MOOC technology to provide **low-cost, high-quality graduate education** in computer science, significantly expanding access to advanced learning globally.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Ramachandran earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from the *University of Wisconsin, Madison* in 1986. He has been a distinguished member of the **Georgia Tech faculty** since then, demonstrating a sustained commitment to research and education.

His leadership roles include serving as the *Chair of the Core Computing Division* (2003-2005), *Director of the STAR Center* (2007-2014), and *Director of Korean Programs for the College of Computing* (2007-2011). His impactful contributions have been recognized with numerous accolades, including an **NSF Presidential Young Investigator Award** (1990), multiple *College of Computing Dean's Awards* (2003, 2014), and elevation to **IEEE Fellow** in 2014 for his significant work in programming idioms for parallel and distributed systems and scalable shared memory systems. He is also a dedicated mentor, having graduated 28 Ph.D. students who now hold prominent positions in academia and industry.

researcher_keywords: Cryptography, Cryptocurrencies, Blockchain, Game Theory, Distributed Computing
paper_abstract: We present a novel Proof-of-Stake (PoS) protocol, Ouroboros Genesis, that enables parties to safely join (or rejoin) the protocol execution using only the genesis block information. Prior to our work, PoS protocols either required parties to obtain a trusted "checkpoint" block upon joining and, furthermore, to be frequently online or required an accurate estimate of the number of online parties to be hardcoded into the protocol logic. This ability of new parties to "bootstrap from genesis" was a hallmark property of the Bitcoin blockchain and was considered an important advantage of PoW-based blockchains over PoS-based blockchains since it facilitates robust operation in a setting with dynamic availability, i.e., the natural setting---without external trusted objects such as checkpoint blocks---where parties come and go arbitrarily, may join at any moment, or remain offline for prolonged periods of time. We prove the security …

## Overview

**Vassilis Zikas** is currently an *Associate Professor* in the **School of Cybersecurity and Privacy** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. He also holds courtesy appointments within Georgia Tech's **School of Computer Science** and the **Computer Science Department** at *Purdue University*. As a pioneer in blockchain and decentralization research, his primary research focuses on foundational aspects of <u>Cryptography</u>, <u>Cryptocurrencies</u>, <u>Blockchain Technologies</u>, <u>Game Theory</u>, <u>Computer Security</u>, and <u>Distributed Computing</u>. Beyond academia, he serves as the *Chief Scientist* of **Sunday Group** and is the lead architect for its flagship **Mobby blockchain**.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Zikas specializes in a diverse array of interconnected research areas, encompassing **Cryptography**, **Cryptocurrencies**, and **Blockchain Technology**, with a significant focus on their theoretical underpinnings and practical applications. His expertise extends to **Game Theory**, particularly its application in cryptographic protocols and rational protocol design, and **Distributed Computing**, including topics such as Distributed Systems and Byzantine Fault Tolerance. He has extensive experience in **Secure Multi-Party Computation (MPC)**, addressing challenges like fairness, robustness, and identifiable abort in adversarial settings. His current work also explores areas like <u>differential privacy estimators</u> and <u>blockchain security against adversaries with temporary majority control</u>.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Zikas co-developed the foundational principles for the decentralization of the **Cardano blockchain** as a research fellow and area leader for IOG (formerly IOHK). This contribution was crucial for the security and operational stability of a major cryptocurrency.
*   He played a key role in introducing **Ouroboros Genesis**, a novel Proof-of-Stake protocol that significantly advanced the ability of new participants to securely join or rejoin blockchain networks using only the genesis block. This innovation mitigated previous requirements for trusted checkpoints or accurate estimations of online parties, enhancing the scalability and robustness of decentralized ledgers.
*   His work includes a **universally composable treatment of the Bitcoin protocol**, which provided a rigorous security analysis that supports the composition of Bitcoin within larger cryptographic systems. This addressed limitations of earlier property-based security proofs, contributing to a more profound understanding and secure integration of Bitcoin.
*   He also made significant contributions to establishing **fair and robust multi-party computation protocols** by leveraging global transaction ledgers like Bitcoin. This research demonstrated how to achieve stronger security guarantees, such as fairness and output delivery, even in the presence of a dishonest majority of participants, addressing a long-standing challenge in cryptographic protocol design.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Zikas earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from *ETH Zurich's Information Security and Cryptography Group* from 2006 to 2010, where his dissertation focused on generalized corruption models in secure multi-party computation under the supervision of Dr. Ueli Maurer. His extensive academic journey includes roles as an *Assistant Professor* at **Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI)**, an *Associate Professor* and *Vice-Director* of the **Blockchain Technology Lab** at the *University of Edinburgh*, and an *Associate Professor* at *Purdue University*, where he founded and directed the **Purdue Blockchain Lab**. He has also served as a *Research Fellow* at the **Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing** at *UC Berkeley* and a *Swiss NSF fellow*. His research is supported by leading government agencies, including the *NSF* and *DoD* in the U.S., and the *Swiss NSF*, alongside substantial grants from industry partners such as **Sunday Group** and the **Algorand Foundation**. He is an active member of the cryptographic community, regularly serving on program committees for top conferences and editorial boards, including the *IACR Journal of Cryptology* and *ACM Transactions on Privacy and Security*. He was recently honored with an **AnlytiXIN Fellowship**.

A high forward current density of 3.77 A mgPt−1 was observed for Pt4Au96, a value two orders of magnitude greater than those observed for core–shell structured Pt78Au22 and a commercial Pt nanocatalyst. ## Overview

**Victor Fung** is currently an *Assistant Professor* in the **School of Computational Science and Engineering** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. A physical chemist by training, his primary research focuses on the <u>intersection of scientific artificial intelligence, computing, and materials science/chemistry</u>. He aims to accelerate the chemical discovery process, with the ultimate goal of fully realizing materials by inverse design, through developing novel computational approaches and data-driven methods.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Fung specializes in a diverse range of research areas, including **Materials Discovery**, **Materials Informatics**, and **Computational Materials Science**, leveraging the power of scientific artificial intelligence and machine learning. His work encompasses **Heterogeneous Catalysis**, **Nanomaterials Synthesis and Characterization**, and **Surface Science**, alongside applications in **Electrocatalysis** and **Oxide Chemistry**. A significant portion of his research involves advanced computational techniques like **Density Functional Theory** to model phenomena at the atomic scale and design new materials atom-by-atom. He also focuses on establishing automated, data-driven ecosystems for materials and chemical discovery, deployable on high-performance supercomputers.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Fung has made significant strides in **electrocatalysis**, demonstrating facile colloidal methods to prepare bimetallic nanoparticles with tailored surface structures, such as platinum-gold systems. This work has led to highly efficient electrocatalysts, showcasing enhanced performance for various reactions.
*   He has contributed to advancing **machine learning in materials chemistry** by benchmarking graph neural networks for diverse applications, from crystal stability to surface chemistry and heterogeneous catalysis. This effort helps standardize the evaluation and development of new machine learning models crucial for accelerating materials discovery.
*   His research also addresses the challenging problem of **low-temperature methane activation**. Notably, he reported a method using H2-reduced phosphomolybdate that achieves almost exclusive conversion of methane and O2 to methanol at room temperature, offering a promising solution for efficient utilization of natural gas.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Fung earned his **B.A. in Chemistry** from *Cornell University* in 2015 and subsequently completed his **Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry** from the *University of California, Riverside*, in 2019. Prior to joining *Georgia Tech* in Fall 2022, he held a prestigious position as a **Wigner Fellow** and was a member of the Nanomaterials Theory Institute in the Center for Nanophase Materials Sciences at *Oak Ridge National Laboratory* from 2019 to 2022. His academic and professional trajectory highlights a strong commitment to interdisciplinary research at the confluence of chemistry, physics, and computational sciences, consistently focusing on data-driven approaches to materials innovation. He is currently the leader of the **Fung Group** at Georgia Tech, mentoring a team of PhD and undergraduate students.

affiliation: Professor, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA
researcher_keywords: SAT/SMT Solvers, AI, software engineering, mathematical logic, quantum foundations
paper_abstract: This article presents EXE, an effective bug-finding tool that automatically generates inputs that crash real code. Instead of running code on manually or randomly constructed input, EXE runs it on symbolic input initially allowed to be anything. As checked code runs, EXE tracks the constraints on each symbolic (i.e., input-derived) memory location. If a statement uses a symbolic value, EXE does not run it, but instead adds it as an input-constraint; all other statements run as usual. If code conditionally checks a symbolic expression, EXE forks execution, constraining the expression to be true on the true branch and false on the other. Because EXE reasons about all possible values on a path, it has much more power than a traditional runtime tool: (1) it can force execution down any feasible program path and (2) at dangerous operations (e.g., a pointer dereference), it detects if the current path constraints allow any value …

## Overview

**Vijay Ganesh** is a *Professor of Computer Science* at the **Georgia Institute of Technology**, having joined in 2023. He also serves as the *Associate Director* of the **IDEaS Institute** and is affiliated with **Tech AI**. His primary research focuses on the <u>theory and practice of SAT/SMT (Satisfiability Modulo Theories) solvers</u> and their applications in various fields including **artificial intelligence, software engineering, security, mathematics, and physics**. Dr. Ganesh's work extends to the critical intersection of <u>learning and reasoning</u>, specifically using **machine learning to enhance solver efficiency** and leveraging solvers to improve the <u>trustworthiness, security, and robustness of AI systems</u>. He is also a co-founder and steering committee member of the **Center for Mathematical AI at the Fields Institute**.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Ganesh specializes in a diverse range of research areas centered around <u>computer-aided reasoning algorithms</u>. His key areas of specialization include **SAT/SMT Solvers, Automated Theorem Proving, Formal Methods, and Software Engineering**, with a strong emphasis on their applications in ensuring **software reliability and security**. He also conducts significant research in **Artificial Intelligence, Mathematical Logic, Constraint Satisfaction, and Programming Languages**, investigating fundamental decidability and complexity results in first-order theories. More recently, his work has expanded into **Machine Learning and Cryptography**, exploring neurosymbolic AI for scientific discovery, mathematics, and code, and integrating machine learning to optimize solver performance.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Ganesh has led the development of several influential SAT/SMT solvers, including **STP, Z3str4, AlphaZ3, MapleSAT, and MathCheck**, which have significantly advanced automated program analysis and bug finding. For instance, the STP solver played a crucial role in developing dynamic symbolic execution, a breakthrough technology used to find numerous security vulnerabilities in software like Debian Linux tools.
*   His contributions include pioneering the integration of machine learning into SMT solvers, as exemplified by the **Z3-alpha solver**. This solver utilizes machine learning to automatically synthesize strategies, dramatically improving efficiency in solving complex logical formulas and setting a new direction for combining automated reasoning with AI.
*   He has also made substantial advancements in **string constraint solving**, developing tools like **Z3-str** and its successors. These solvers are vital for analyzing web applications and identifying security errors related to string manipulation, addressing a critical need in web security analysis.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Ganesh earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from *Stanford University* in 2007. His career trajectory includes a tenure as a *Research Scientist* at the **Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)** from 2007 to 2012, followed by a period as an *Associate Professor* at the **University of Waterloo** from 2012 to 2023, where he also co-directed the **Waterloo AI Institute** from 2021 to 2023.

He joined **Georgia Tech** in 2023 as a *Professor of Computer Science*. Dr. Ganesh has received extensive recognition for his research, accumulating **over 30 awards, honors, and medals**, including an *ACM Impact Paper Award* at ISSTA 2019, an *ACM Test of Time Award* at CCS 2016, and a *Ten-Year Most Influential Paper citation* at DATE 2008. These accolades underscore his consistent and significant contributions to the fields of automated reasoning and computer science.

affiliation: Professor of Cybersecurity & Privacy, Georgia Tech
researcher_keywords: Wireless, Computers, Software, Electronics, Information Systems
paper_abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) are being adopted for industrial and manufacturing applications such as manufacturing automation, remote machine diagnostics, prognostic health management of industrial machines and supply chain management. Cloud-Based Manufacturing is a recent on-demand model of manufacturing that is leveraging IoT technologies. While Cloud-Based Manufacturing enables on-demand access to manufacturing resources, a trusted intermediary is required for transactions between the users who wish to avail manufacturing services. We present a decentralized, peer-to-peer platform called BPIIoT for Industrial Internet of Things based on the Block chain technology. With the use of Blockchain technology, the BPIIoT platform enables peers in a decentralized, trustless, peer-to-peer network to interact with each other without the need for a trusted intermediary.

## Overview

**Vijay Madisetti** is currently a *Professor of Cybersecurity & Privacy* at the **Georgia Institute of Technology**. In this capacity, he directs numerous research and educational initiatives spanning <u>digital signal processing, embedded computing systems, chip design, wireless and telecom systems, and systems engineering</u>. Dr. Madisetti also serves as the *Executive Director* of **Georgia Tech's India Initiative**. His primary research endeavors focus on advancing the fields of <u>cybersecurity, blockchain technology, and the Internet of Things (IoT)</u>, alongside foundational work in computer systems and signal processing.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Madisetti specializes in a comprehensive array of research domains, with a strong emphasis on **Wireless Communications**, **Computer Systems**, and **Software Engineering**. His expertise extends to the intricate aspects of <u>Electronics, Information Systems, and Digital Signal Processing (DSP)</u>. A significant portion of his work explores emerging technologies like **Blockchain Technology**, the **Internet of Things (IoT)**, and **Cloud Computing**, focusing on their applications and underlying system designs. Furthermore, his research encompasses **Embedded Systems**, **Computer Networking**, **Data Science and Analytics**, and fundamental **Cybersecurity** principles.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Madisetti has made significant contributions to the field of **Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT)** by developing a <u>blockchain platform</u> that enhances trust and efficiency in manufacturing automation, remote diagnostics, and supply chain management. This work addresses critical needs for secure and reliable transactions in cloud-based manufacturing environments.
*   He has also been instrumental in shaping the understanding and application of **Digital Signal Processing** through authoring a highly cited <u>handbook</u> that serves as a fundamental resource for both theoretical and practical aspects of signal processing, contributing to advancements in various engineering applications.
*   His research has advanced the design of <u>interoperable electronic health record (EHR) systems</u> by leveraging **cloud computing environments**, offering substantial benefits to healthcare stakeholders by facilitating seamless data exchange and improving patient care through efficient information management.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Madisetti earned his **Bachelor of Technology (Honors)** in *Electronics and Electrical Communications Engineering* from the **Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kharagpur**, in 1984. He then pursued and completed his **Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences** at the *University of California at Berkeley* in 1989.

He joined the faculty of **Georgia Tech's School of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE)** in the same year, 1989, where he has since built a distinguished career. Dr. Madisetti is a recognized **Fellow of the IEEE** and was honored with the <u>2006 Frederick Emmons Terman Medal</u> by the **American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE)** and HP Corporations for his profound contributions to electrical engineering education. Additionally, he received the **Georgia Tech Doctoral Thesis Advisor Award** in 2001, underscoring his commitment to mentoring future researchers.

paper_abstract: It is now well established that the device scaling predicted by Moore's Law is no longer a viable option for increasing the clock frequency of future uniprocessor systems at the rate that had been sustained during the last two decades. As a result, future systems are rapidly moving from uniprocessor to multiprocessor configurations, so as to use parallelism instead of frequency scaling as the foundation for increased compute capacity. The dominant emerging multiprocessor structure for the future is a Non-Uniform Cluster Computing (NUCC) system with nodes that are built out of multi-core SMP chips with non-uniform memory hierarchies, and interconnected in horizontally scalable cluster configurations such as blade servers. Unlike previous generations of hardware evolution, this shift will have a major impact on existing software. Current OO language facilities for concurrent and distributed programming are …

## Overview

**Vivek Sarkar** is currently the <u>John P. Imlay, Jr. Dean of the College of Computing</u> at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*, a position he assumed effective June 2024, where he also serves as a professor in the **School of Computer Science**. Prior to this, he was the Chair of the School of Computer Science and held the Stephen Fleming Chair for Telecommunications at Georgia Tech. He leads the **Habanero Extreme Scale Software Research Laboratory** at Georgia Tech, focusing his primary research on multiple aspects of <u>programmability and performance for high-performance computing</u>. His work spans programming languages, compilers, runtime systems, and debugging tools for parallel, heterogeneous, and distributed computer systems.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Sarkar specializes in a comprehensive array of research areas crucial for advanced computing. His expertise encompasses **Parallel Computing**, including parallel programming models, parallelizing compilers, and parallel runtime systems, along with **Programming Languages** and **Compilers**. He also conducts significant work in **Program Analysis** and the design of **Runtime Systems**, particularly for high-performance and extreme-scale platforms. Beyond these core areas, his research interests extend to *Computer Architecture, Operating Systems, Distributed Systems, Software Engineering,* and *Artificial Intelligence*, often with an emphasis on making future high-performance computers easier to program and more efficient.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Sarkar played a pivotal role in the development of **X10**, an innovative object-oriented programming language designed for non-uniform cluster computing, which significantly advanced the field of programming for distributed parallel systems by serving as a research sandbox for high-performance computing.
*   His foundational contributions to **partitioning and scheduling parallel programs** for execution on multiprocessors addressed the critical challenge of optimizing the trade-off between parallelism and communication overhead, leading to more efficient utilization of multiprocessor systems. This early work laid groundwork for compiler and runtime system development in parallel computing.
*   He made significant advancements in the design of efficient virtual machines and optimizing compilers for object-oriented languages, exemplified by his work on the **Jikes Research Virtual Machine (Jikes RVM)** and its dynamic optimizing compiler. This research was instrumental in enabling high-performance execution of Java applications on server machines and influencing subsequent open-source research communities.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Sarkar earned his **Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering** from *IIT Kanpur in 1981*, followed by his **Master's degree in Computer Science** from the *University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1982*, and his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from *Stanford University in 1987*, where he was advised by Professor John Hennessy. He commenced his career at **IBM Research**, contributing to projects such as the PTRAN automatic parallelization system and the ASTI optimizer, and was a member of the *IBM Academy of Technology* from 1997 to 2007.

After a distinguished career in industry, he transitioned to academia, first at *Rice University* from 2007 to 2017 as the E.D. Butcher Chair in Engineering and Chair of the Department of Computer Science, and subsequently to *Georgia Tech* in 2017. He has been recognized as a **Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM)** since 2008 and a **Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)**, and is the recipient of the **2020 ACM-IEEE CS Ken Kennedy Award** for his foundational contributions to parallel computing and leadership in professional service, mentoring, and teaching. researcher_keywords: Cryptography, security, secure computation, zero knowledge proofs
paper_abstract: We present a new garbled circuit construction for two-party secure function evaluation (SFE). In our one-round protocol, XOR gates are evaluated “for free”, which results in the corresponding improvement over the best garbled circuit implementations (e.g. Fairplay [19]).We build permutation networks [26] and Universal Circuits (UC) [25] almost exclusively of XOR gates; this results in a factor of up to 4 improvement (in both computation and communication) of their SFE. We also improve integer addition and equality testing by factor of up to 2.We rely on the Random Oracle (RO) assumption. Our constructions are proven secure in the semi-honest model.

## Overview

His primary research focuses on the <u>practical and foundational aspects of secure computation</u>, particularly two-party computation and achieving cryptographic and privacy goals through technologies like **blockchain**. He actively investigates improving and utilizing techniques such as *garbled circuits*, *homomorphic encryption*, and various related cryptographic methods.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Kolesnikov specializes in a wide array of research areas within **cryptography** and <u>security</u>, with a strong emphasis on **secure computation**. His expertise spans topics including *secure multi-party computation*, **zero-knowledge proofs**, and *garbled circuits*, which are fundamental to building privacy-preserving applications. Additionally, his work delves into practical applications of **applied cryptography**, covering areas like *private set intersection*, **oblivious transfer**, and the crucial field of *database privacy*. His research also extends to **information security architecture** and the complex challenges of <u>cyber-physical systems security</u>, encompassing the design and analysis of secure systems like smart grid networks and wireless authentication.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Kolesnikov has made significant contributions to advancing **garbled circuit technology**, introducing innovations like "free XOR gates" and flexible garbling, which have substantially *improved the efficiency of two-party secure function evaluation* by reducing computation and communication overheads. These advancements have enabled more practical and widespread deployment of secure computation solutions.
*   He played a key role in developing a <u>scalable private database management system</u>, "Blind Seer," which provides both client query privacy and server data protection while supporting rich query sets. This work addresses a major challenge in private databases, demonstrating **efficient sublinear search for arbitrary Boolean queries** with provable security.
*   His research also led to the creation of efficient protocols for <u>oblivious pseudorandom functions (OPRF)</u> and **multi-party private set intersection (PSI)** based on symmetric-key techniques. These contributions avoid computationally expensive public-key operations and are practical for various applications where parties need to compute intersections of their datasets without revealing additional information.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Kolesnikov earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from the *University of Toronto* in 2006, where his doctoral thesis focused on secure two-party computation and communication. Prior to joining *Georgia Tech*, he served as a **Member of the Technical Staff** in *Bell Labs' Enabling Computing Technologies domain* in Murray Hill, NJ, where he conducted research on secure multi-party computation and key exchange. His career trajectory includes significant involvement in industrial research and serving on standards committees like WiMAX, demonstrating a strong commitment to translating theoretical cryptographic research into practical, secure systems. He has been a principal investigator on projects for entities such as the Office of Naval Research and IARPA, and his extensive publication record includes numerous papers and patent applications, reflecting his significant influence in the field of cryptography and security.

researcher_keywords: Human-computer interaction
paper_abstract: The smart home offers a new opportunity to augment people’s lives with ubiquitous computing technology that provides increased communications, awareness, and functionality. Recently, a number of trends have increased the likelihood that the aware home can soon become a reality. We examine a number of challenges from the technical, social, and pragmatic domains that we feel must be overcome before the vision of the smart home, posited by ubiquitous computing research, can become a reality. Our hope in raising these issues is to create a conversation among researchers in the varied disciplines that make up ubiquitous computing. In particular, we hope to raise awareness of the existing literature on the adoption, use, and history of domestic technologies, as well as the use of situated studies, and the benefits that these can bring to bear on the design and evaluation of technologies for the home

researcher_keywords: Natural Language Processing, Social Media, Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Most recent sentence simplification systems use basic machine translation models                     to learn lexical and syntactic paraphrases from a manually simplified parallel                     corpus. These methods are limited by the quality and quantity of manually                     simplified corpora, which are expensive to build. In this paper, we conduct an                     in-depth adaptation of statistical machine translation to perform text                     simplification, taking advantage of large-scale paraphrases learned from                     bilingual texts and a small amount of manual simplifications with multiple                     references. Our work is the first to design automatic metrics that are effective                     for tuning and evaluating simplification systems, which will facilitate                     iterative development for this task.

paper_abstract: In this paper we discuss our research in developing general and systematic methods for intrusion detection. The key ideas are to use data mining techniques to discover consistent and useful patterns of system features that describe program and user behavior, and use the set of relevant system features to compute (inductively learned) classifiers that can recognize anomalies and known intrusions. Using experiments on the sendmail system call data and the network tcpdump data, we demonstrate that we can construct concise and accurate classifiers to detect anomalies. We provide an overview on two general data mining algorithms that we have implemented: the association rules algorithm and the frequent episodes algorithm. These algorithms can be used to compute the intra-and inter-audit record patterns, which are essential in describing program or user behavior. The discovered patterns can guide the audit …

A significant portion of his work involves **Machine Learning for Security**, where he has applied data mining techniques to develop advanced **Intrusion Detection Systems** and **Anomaly Detection** mechanisms.

His specialization further extends to proactive threat intelligence, such as **Malware Analysis**, **Botnet Detection**, and **Virtualization Security**. ## Notable Works

*   Dr. Lee pioneered the application of **data mining techniques to intrusion detection**, developing systematic and adaptive frameworks that enabled the automatic discovery of consistent patterns in system and user behavior. researcher_keywords: Mathematics and Computer Science
paper_abstract: The problem of identifying a planted assignment given a random k-SAT formula consistent with the assignment exhibits a large algorithmic gap: while the planted solution can always be identified given a formula with O(n log n) clauses, there are distributions over clauses for which the best known efficient algorithms require nk/2 clauses. We propose and study a unified model for planted k-SAT, which captures well-known special cases. An instance is described by a planted assignment σ and a distribution on clauses with k literals. We define its distribution complexity as the largest r for which the distribution is not r-wise independent (1 ≤ r ≤ k for any distribution with a planted assignment). Our main result is an unconditional lower bound, tight up to logarithmic factors, of Ω(nr/2) clauses for statistical algorithms, matching the known upper bound (which, as we show, can be implemented using a statistical algorithm …

researcher_keywords: Computational biology, Algorithms
paper_abstract: Single-cell RNA-seq can yield valuable insights about the variability within a population of seemingly homogeneous cells. We developed a quantitative statistical method to distinguish true biological variability from the high levels of technical noise in single-cell experiments. Our approach quantifies the statistical significance of observed cell-to-cell variability in expression strength on a gene-by-gene basis. We validate our approach using two independent data sets from Arabidopsis thaliana and Mus musculus.

researcher_keywords: Efficient AI algorithms, Deep learning accelerators, Green AI
paper_abstract: (Frankle & Carbin, 2019) shows that there exist winning tickets (small but critical subnetworks) for dense, randomly initialized networks, that can be trained alone to achieve comparable accuracies to the latter in a similar number of iterations. However, the identification of these winning tickets still requires the costly train-prune-retrain process, limiting their practical benefits. In this paper, we discover for the first time that the winning tickets can be identified at the very early training stage, which we term as early-bird (EB) tickets, via low-cost training schemes (e.g., early stopping and low-precision training) at large learning rates. Our finding of EB tickets is consistent with recently reported observations that the key connectivity patterns of neural networks emerge early. Furthermore, we propose a mask distance metric that can be used to identify EB tickets with low computational overhead, without needing to know the true winning tickets that emerge after the full training. Finally, we leverage the existence of EB tickets and the proposed mask distance to develop efficient training methods, which are achieved by first identifying EB tickets via low-cost schemes, and then continuing to train merely the EB tickets towards the target accuracy. Experiments based on various deep networks and datasets validate: 1) the existence of EB tickets, and the effectiveness of mask distance in efficiently identifying them; and 2) that the proposed efficient training via EB tickets can achieve up to 4.7x energy savings while maintaining comparable or even better accuracy, demonstrating a promising and easily adopted method for tackling cost-prohibitive deep network training …

researcher_keywords: Networking, Distributed Systems, P2P, Internet measurement
paper_abstract: We present Dasu, a measurement experimentation platform for the Internet’s edge. Dasu supports both controlled network experimentation and broadband characterization, building on public interest on the latter to gain the adoption necessary for the former. We discuss some of the challenges we faced building a platform for the Internet’s edge, describe our current design and implementation, and illustrate the unique perspective it brings to Internet measurement. Dasu has been publicly available since July 2010 and has been installed by over 90,000 users with a heterogeneous set of connections spreading across 1,802 networks and 147 countries.

More generally, for any antiferromagnetic 2-spin system we prove O(nlogn) mixing time of the Glauber dynamics on any bounded degree graph in the corresponding tree …
