affiliation: Associate Professor, Georgia Institute of Technology
researcher_keywords: Machine Learning, Perception, Robotics, Artificial Intelligence
paper_abstract: Few-shot classification aims to learn a classifier to recognize unseen classes during training with limited labeled examples. While significant progress has been made, the growing complexity of network designs, meta-learning algorithms, and differences in implementation details make a fair comparison difficult. In this paper, we present 1) a consistent comparative analysis of several representative few-shot classification algorithms, with results showing that deeper backbones significantly reduce the performance differences among methods on datasets with limited domain differences, 2) a modified baseline method that surprisingly achieves competitive performance when compared with the state-of-the-art on both the \miniI and the CUB datasets, and 3) a new experimental setting for evaluating the cross-domain generalization ability for few-shot classification algorithms. Our results reveal that reducing intra-class variation is an important factor when the feature backbone is shallow, but not as critical when using deeper backbones. In a realistic cross-domain evaluation setting, we show that a baseline method with a standard fine-tuning practice compares favorably against other state-of-the-art few-shot learning algorithms.

affiliation: Professor of Computer Science, Georgia Tech
researcher_keywords: theoretical computer science
paper_abstract: Recently, Fredman and Tarjan invented a new, especially efficient form of heap (priority queue). Their data structure, theFibonacci heap (or F-heap) supports arbitrary deletion inO(logn) amortized time and other heap operations inO(1) amortized time. In this paper we use F-heaps to obtain fast algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees in undirected and directed graphs. For an undirected graph containingn vertices andm edges, our minimum spanning tree algorithm runs inO(m logβ (m, n)) time, improved fromO(mβ(m, n)) time, whereβ(m, n)=min {i|log(i)n ≦m/n}. Our minimum spanning tree algorithm for directed graphs runs inO(n logn + m) time, improved fromO(n log n +m log log log(m/n+2)n). Both algorithms can be extended to allow a degree constraint at one vertex.

## Overview

**Zvi Galil** is currently the *Frederick G. Storey Chair in Computing* and an **Executive Advisor to Online Programs** at the Georgia Institute of Technology. After serving as the <u>Dean of the Georgia Tech College of Computing</u> from 2010 to 2019, his primary research continues to focus on the **design and analysis of algorithms**, <u>computational complexity</u>, and **cryptography**. He is also highly recognized for his significant contributions to computer science education, particularly in online learning initiatives.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Galil specializes in a wide array of theoretical computer science disciplines, including **Algorithms and Data Structures**, **Graph Theory**, <u>Computational Complexity</u>, and **Combinatorial Optimization**. His work further extends into specialized fields such as **Stringology** (a term he is credited with coining), **Parallel and Distributed Computing**, and **Cryptography**. Additionally, he has conducted important research in the **Design of Experiments** and <u>Discrete Mathematics</u>.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Galil was a driving force behind the establishment of the **Online Master of Science in Computer Science (OMSCS) program** at Georgia Tech, co-conceiving it with Udacity founder Sebastian Thrun. This innovative program revolutionized graduate education by offering a <u>high-quality, low-cost online master's degree</u>, significantly expanding access to advanced computer science education globally and becoming the largest program of its kind in the United States.
*   He made fundamental contributions to the **design and analysis of algorithms**, developing more than a dozen of the fastest algorithms for both exact and approximate string matching, including sequential, parallel, one-dimensional, and multi-dimensional variations. His work also produced efficient algorithms for problems such as <u>maximal weighted matching</u>, trivalent graph isomorphism, and minimum weight spanning trees.
*   Dr. Galil introduced the algorithmic technique of "**sparsification**," which significantly sped up dynamic graph algorithms, and developed "sparse dynamic programming" to accelerate computations related to various edit distances between strings. These techniques have had a profound impact on the efficiency of numerous computational problems.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Galil earned his **B.Sc. (1970)** and **M.Sc. (1971)** degrees in *Applied Mathematics*, both summa cum laude, from Tel Aviv University. He then completed his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from *Cornell University* in 1975, under the supervision of John Hopcroft.

His extensive career trajectory includes a postdoctoral research position at *IBM's Thomas J. Watson Research Center*, followed by faculty appointments at **Tel Aviv University** and **Columbia University**, where he served as department chair and later as the *Morris and Alma A. Schapiro Dean of Engineering*. He also served as the **President of Tel Aviv University** from 2007 to 2009.

Dr. Galil is an **ACM Fellow** (1995), a member of the **National Academy of Engineering** (2004), and a **Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences** (2005). He has received numerous accolades, including the <u>Great Teacher Award</u> from the Columbia Society of Graduates (2009) and an <u>honorary Doctor of Mathematics degree</u> from the University of Waterloo (2012). In 2020, he was recognized by Academic Influence as one of the <u>10 most influential computer scientists of the last decade</u>, and an endowed chair was established in his name at Georgia Tech. He continues to be recognized for his professional service, having chaired ACM SIGACT and served as editor-in-chief for prominent academic journals.

researcher_keywords: Startup engineering
paper_abstract: We introduce a new approach to planning in STRIPS-like domains based on constructing and analyzing a compact structure we call a planning graph. We describe a new planner, Graphplan, that uses this paradigm. Graphplan always returns a shortest possible partial-order plan, or states that no valid plan exists. We provide empirical evidence in favor of this approach, showing that Graphplan outperforms the total-order planner, Prodigy and the partial-order planner, UCPOP, on a variety of interesting natural and artificial planning problems. We also give empirical evidence that the plans produced by Graphplan are quite sensible. Since searches made by this approach are fundamentally different from the searches of other common planning methods, they provide a new perspective on the planning problem.

## Overview

**Dr. Merrick L. Furst** is a *Distinguished Professor* in the **College of Computing** at the *Georgia Institute of Technology*. He currently serves as the **Director of the Center for Deliberate Innovation** at Georgia Tech, where he oversees commercialization, new venture creation, and directs undergraduate programs and faculty development. His primary research encompasses <u>seminal contributions in algorithms, complexity theory, and Artificial Intelligence (AI)</u>. Dr. Furst also focuses on *startup engineering and fostering deliberate innovation*, guiding emerging leaders and technology ventures.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Furst's expertise spans a broad spectrum of computational fields, including **Theoretical Computer Science**, **Algorithms and Data Structures**, and **Computational Complexity**. He is highly recognized for his work in **Machine Learning Theory**, **Cryptography**, and **Graph Theory**. His research also delves into *Programming Languages and Compilers, Human-Computer Interaction, Artificial Intelligence*, and **Computer Science Education**, with a recent emphasis on <u>startup engineering and the discipline of deliberate innovation</u>.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Furst is a co-inventor of **planning graphs**, a significant advancement in AI planning that introduced a novel approach to fast planning in STRIPS-like domains. This work revolutionized how optimal partial-order plans are generated or how the absence of a valid plan is determined.
*   He also co-invented **probabilistic circuit analysis**, a foundational contribution in computational complexity theory. This research established super-polynomial lower bounds for fixed-depth circuits computing functions like parity, influencing the understanding of circuit limitations.
*   Dr. Furst played a pivotal role in creating the **"Threads" curriculum** at Georgia Tech, a new structuring principle for computing curricula. This innovative educational model aims to prepare computer science graduates to thrive in a competitive global environment by developing leadership, innovation, and insightful thinking.
*   Furthermore, he is recognized for founding **Flashpoint@GT**, now the Center for Deliberate Innovation, a unique startup engineering studio dedicated to cultivating formative leaders and exceptional technology startups, and for co-founding the anti-botnet startup, **Damballa, Inc.**

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Furst earned his **Ph.D. in Computer Science** from *Cornell University*. His extensive career trajectory includes serving as a *professor and Associate Dean in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University*. Prior to his tenure at Georgia Tech, he was a *professor at UC Berkeley* and the *President of the International Computer Science Institute at Berkeley*, in addition to being the *CEO of Essential Surfing Gear, Inc.* He was also instrumental in establishing a new high school in San Francisco. Dr. Furst's innovative contributions to computer science education and his ideas for the Georgia Tech Computing program have been acknowledged by notable authors, including Thomas L. Friedman in "The World is Flat." He is also the co-author of the book, "The Heart of Innovation: A Field Guide for Navigating to Authentic Demand."

## Overview

**Seth Hutchinson** is currently a *Professor* in the **Khoury College of Computer Sciences** at *Northeastern University*, holding a joint appointment with the **College of Engineering**, effective January 2025. His primary research endeavors are dedicated to advancing the capabilities and intelligence of robots. He focuses on fundamental aspects of <u>robotics, encompassing planning, sensing, and control</u>, with a strong motivation to make robotic systems more adept and versatile in various environments.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Hutchinson specializes in a broad spectrum of robotics research, including **Robot Control**, **Motion Planning**, and **Computer Vision**. His work extensively covers **Visual Servoing**, which involves using visual feedback for robot control, and the development of **Multi-Robot Systems** and **Autonomous Systems**. Further areas of expertise include **Trajectory Generation**, the application of **Machine Learning** in robotics, and **Biologically Inspired Robotics**, particularly in the study of locomotion. Additionally, his research delves into *physical human-robot interaction, planning under uncertainty, pursuit and evasion, and localization and mapping*.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Hutchinson co-authored influential textbooks such as "Robot Modeling and Control" and "Principles of Robot Motion: Theory, Algorithms, and Implementations," which have become **foundational texts** in the field. These works have significantly contributed to making the *mathematical and algorithmic underpinnings of robot motion and control* accessible to students and researchers, thereby shaping the education and advancement of robotics worldwide.
*   He has made substantial contributions to the field of **visual servo control**, a crucial technology that enables robots to use computer vision to guide their movements. His research has explored both *image-based and position-based approaches*, addressing key challenges in performance and stability, which has led to more robust and accurate robotic manipulation and interaction with the environment.
*   His innovative work includes the development of **biomimetic robotic platforms**, notably the "Bat Bot (B2)," a biologically inspired flying machine. This project demonstrated significant advancements in understanding complex locomotion and agility by mimicking the intricate flight mechanisms of bats, contributing valuable insights to both *biology and aerial robotics*.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Seth Hutchinson earned his **Ph.D., M.S., and B.S. degrees in Electrical Engineering** from *Purdue University* in 1988, 1984, and 1983, respectively.

His distinguished career trajectory includes serving for 28 years at the *University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign*, where he is now an **Emeritus Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering**. From 2018 to 2024, he was a **Professor and KUKA Chair for Robotics** in the School of Interactive Computing and the **Executive Director of the Institute for Robotics and Intelligent Machines (IRIM)** at *Georgia Institute of Technology*. He commenced his role at *Northeastern University* in January 2025.

Dr. Hutchinson has held prominent leadership positions, including serving as **President of the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society (RAS)**, **Editor-in-Chief of IEEE Transactions on Robotics**, and founding Editor-in-Chief of the RAS Conference Editorial Board. He is also recognized as an **IEEE Fellow** and is actively involved with the *Institute for Experiential Robotics* at Northeastern University.

paper_abstract: In this work, we show that the standard graph-partitioning-based decomposition of sparse matrices does not reflect the actual communication volume requirement for parallel matrix-vector multiplication. We propose two computational hypergraph models which avoid this crucial deficiency of the graph model. The proposed models reduce the decomposition problem to the well-known hypergraph partitioning problem. The recently proposed successful multilevel framework is exploited to develop a multilevel hypergraph partitioning tool PaToH for the experimental verification of our proposed hypergraph models. Experimental results on a wide range of realistic sparse test matrices confirm the validity of the proposed hypergraph models. In the decomposition of the test matrices, the hypergraph models using PaToH and hMeTiS result in up to 63 percent less communication volume (30 to 38 percent less on the average …

## Overview

**Dr. Ümit V. Çatalyürek** is currently a distinguished *Professor* in the **School of Computational Science and Engineering** within the *College of Computing* at the **Georgia Institute of Technology**. He also holds the position of Associate Chair for Academic Programs at Georgia Tech and concurrently serves as an Amazon Scholar. His primary research endeavors revolve around <u>high-performance computing, combinatorial scientific computing, and biomedical informatics</u>, focusing on developing scalable algorithms and computational models for complex scientific and data-intensive applications.

---

## Research Areas

Dr. Çatalyürek specializes in a broad spectrum of research areas, including **Combinatorial Scientific Computing**, **High Performance Computing**, and **Parallel Computing**. His expertise also spans into *Biomedical Informatics*, encompassing areas such as **Graph Algorithms**, *Machine Learning*, **Image Analysis**, *Computational Science*, **Data Mining**, and *Scientific Visualization*. He is particularly interested in graph and hypergraph partitioning, workload and data decomposition for irregular domains, scheduling, and the development of parallel algorithms for both scientific and biomedical applications. His work often involves multidisciplinary studies connecting algorithm design, computation theory, centrality analysis, and combinatorics.

---

## Notable Works

*   Dr. Çatalyürek has made fundamental contributions to <u>optimizing parallel computations for sparse matrices</u> by developing innovative hypergraph models and partitioning tools. His work significantly enhances load balancing and minimizes communication overhead in high-performance computing environments, accelerating complex scientific simulations across various disciplines.
*   He has pioneered the creation of <u>scalable parallel algorithms for large-scale graph analysis</u>, including distributed breadth-first search, k-core decomposition, and betweenness centrality. These advancements are critical for efficiently processing massive graph datasets in emerging data science applications, network analysis, and bioinformatics, enabling deeper insights into complex system structures.
*   His research has also profoundly impacted <u>biomedical informatics and digital pathology</u> through the development of computer-aided diagnosis and prognosis systems for cancers like neuroblastoma and follicular lymphoma. Additionally, he has contributed to methods for analyzing high-dimensional biological data, such as gene expression and next-generation sequencing reads, which are vital for accelerating biological discovery and improving clinical decision-making.

---

## Academic Background

Dr. Çatalyürek earned his **B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees** in *Computer Engineering and Information Science* from **Bilkent University, Turkey**, in 1992, 1994, and 2000, respectively, with his doctoral research supervised by Dr. Cevdet Aykanat. Prior to joining *Georgia Tech* in 2016, he held positions as a Professor and Vice Chair in the Department of Biomedical Informatics, and as a Professor in Electrical & Computer Engineering and Computer Science & Engineering at the *Ohio State University*.

His distinguished career includes being named an **IEEE Fellow** in 2016 and a **SIAM Fellow** in 2020 for his significant contributions to combinatorial scientific computing and parallel algorithms. He is a recipient of an **NSF CAREER award** and currently serves as the **Editor-in-Chief for Parallel Computing**. Dr. Çatalyürek is also a member of the Board of Trustees of Bilkent University and has held leadership roles, including Chair for IEEE TCPP and Vice-Chair for ACM SIGBio.
